documents.title: Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) Donning Checklist
content: 1. This checklist is designed as abroad checklist to ensure safety in donning PPE. You must:
<tab2>a. Determine the appropriate level of PPE (Contact, Droplet,Airborne) by referring to the Ornge Infection Prevention & Control Resource Manual.</tab2>
<tab2>b. Don only the PPE items required in the order outlined below.</tab2>
2. Review the procedure list with your partner or other healthcare professional before the donning procedure.
3. Attend to personal needs,hydrate, tie back long hair andsecure in place. Remove hand and wrist jewelry.
4. Gather and inspect the required PPE. Do not use items that are grossly soiled or damaged.
<color=Document Orange>Use alcohol-based hand rub (ABHR) or soap and water before putting on any PPE
<color=Document Orange>Allow hands to dry completely before putting on any PPE
<color=Document Orange>Select coverall/gown large enough to allow unrestricted freedom of movement
<color=Document Orange>Apply respirator as per manufacturer user instructions
<color=Document Orange>Flex nose piece to the bridge of the nose
<color=Document Orange>Apply recommended safety eyewear as per manufacturer’s user instructions
PUT ON FACE PROTECTION/SHIELD *REQUIRED DURING ALL AEROSOL-GENERATING PROCEDURES
<color=Document Orange>Apply full face shield as per manufacturers userinstructions
<color=Document Orange>Ensure face shield provides coverage of entire front and sides of the face; adjust as required
Ensure gloves cover cuffs of coverall/gown and that no skin is exposed<color=Document Orange>
Adjust and verify the proper fit of PPE<color=Document Orange>
Inspect PPE to ensure it is secure and desired level of protection has been achieved<color=Document Orange>
Visually confirm sequence has been completed correctly<color=Document Orange>

Looking for more informaton? Please contact Justin Smith, Chief Flight Paramedic, at jsmith@ornge.ca.
You can also visit our intranet website to view updates: https://compass.ornge.ca<text_color=#FFFFFFFF><color=#FF5900FF>

documents.title: Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) Doffing Checklist
content: This checklist is designed to ensure safety in doffing PPE. You must:
<tab2>a. Determine the appropriate level of PPE (Contact, Droplet,Airborne) by referring to theOrnge Infection Prevention & Control Resource Manual.</tab2>
<tab2>b. Don/dof only the PPE items required in the order outlined below.</tab2>
2. Where possible, consult with healthcare facility staff on the best area in which to undertake the doffing procedure.
3. Consider asking a healthcare professional to help use thechecklist as a trained observer.
4. Ensure the doffing area has the required equipment and biohazardous waste bins/bag/receptacles.
5. Review the doffing procedurechecklist before undertaking thedoffing procedure
6. Yellow are the normal steps - Green is optional assessment.
Do not remove gown at this stage<color=Document Yellow>
Dispose into the designated waste container<color=Document Yellow>
A trained observer may assist but must be donned in appropriate PPE based on risk<color=Document Yellow>

Unzip or unfasten coverall/gown completely before rolling down and turning inside out. Avoid contact of inner clothing with the outer surface of coverall during removal, touching inside of the coverall/gown only.<color=Document Yellow>
Dispose into the designated waste container<color=Document Yellow>
Use alcohol-based hand rub (ABHR) and/or soap and water<color=Document Yellow>
Allow hands to dry completely<color=Document Yellow>
REMOVE SAFETY EYEWEAR +/- FACE SHIELD (IF APPLICABLE)
Remove safety eyewear by grabbing at arms (temples) at side of head, taking care not to touch outside of frame or lens.<color=Document Yellow>
Inspect hands - PERFORM HAND HYGIENE if hands contaminated from removing eyewear
Use alcohol-based hand rub (ABHR) and/or soap and water<color=Document Green>
Allow hands to dry completely<color=Document Green>
Grab bottom strap and lift over head<color=Document Yellow>
Lean forward and grab top strap; gently lift over head and away from face<color=Document Yellow>
Take care not to touch the front of the respirator<color=Document Yellow>
Dispose into designated waste container<color=Document Yellow>
Use alcohol-based hand rub (ABHR) and/or soap and water<color=Document Yellow>
Allow hands to dry completely<color=Document Yellow>
Visually confirm sequence has been completed correctly and no contamination has occurred<color=Document Yellow>

Looking for more informaton? Please contact Justin Smith, Chief Flight Paramedic, at jsmith@ornge.ca.
You can also visit our intranet website to view updates: https://compass.ornge.ca<text_color=#FFFFFFFF><color=#FF5900FF>

documents.title: Controlled Intubation Checklist
content: Patient Positioning (E2SN, Head Up, Umbilical Height)
Pre-oxygenation (Mask O2 > 15LPM + Nasal O2 15 LPM > NIPPV > BVM + PEEP)
30 Second Drills Briefed = NECK – HEAD – HANDS – SCOOP – PULL BACK
BVM (Assembled = PEEP – Manometer – Filter – Extender – ETC02 - Mask)
Cric Set & Assessment (> 12 yrs of age)
ETT/ SGA Placement Confirmed with ETCO2
ETT/ SGA Secured, Depth Confirmed, Cuff Pressure 20-30 cm H2O
Ventilator – Settings, Circuit, In-Line Suction, Filter, ETCO2
Supplies – Oxygen, Drugs, Power, Airway Bag Packed Up
BVM (Assembled = PEEP – Manometer – Filter – Extender – ETC02 - Mask)

documents.title: Adult - Supraglottic Airway
documents.indications:
• Weight > 2 kg
• Need for ventilatory assistance OR airway control AND
• Other airway management is inadequate OR ineffective OR unsuccessful
documents.contraindications:
• Intact gag reflex
• Caustic ingestion
• Active vomiting
documents.clinical:
• Supraglottic airway should be the initial airway strategy in out of hospital cardiac arrest unless endotracheal intubation is deemed more appropriate by the paramedic
• Endotracheal intubation is usually preferred for secure airway management in the non cardiac arrest patient. In this setting, SGA is considered a rescue device if BLS airway/ventilation and other advanced airway maneuvers have been unsuccessful
• MUST confirm placement with EtCO2 waveform (+ chest rise)

drug_cards.title: Supraglottic Airway
dose_route:
<center>Insert Airway
MAX 2 attempts

If two (2) attempts at supraglottic airway have failed, then revert to BVM and oral / nasal pharyngeal airway management</center>

documents.title: Adult - Cricothyrotomy
documents.indications:
• CVCO - Can’t Ventilate, Can’t Oxygenate situation
• Need for ventilatory assistance OR airway control AND
• Other airway management is inadequate OR ineffective OR unsuccessful
documents.contraindications:
• <12 years of age
• Suspected fractured larynx
• Inability to landmark or distorted neck anatomy
• Relative: expanding neck hematomas or other pathologies distorting neck structures
documents.clinical: • MUST confirm placement with EtC02 waveform (+ chest rise) • Provide post cricothyrotomy sedation and paralysis as per Sedation and Pain Management for Intubated and Ventilated Patients and Post Intubation Paralysis Medical Directives • Post cricothyrotomy - adjust ventilation strategies for small lumen • Cricothyrotomy tube placement must be reconfirmed immediately after each patient movement

documents.title: Adult - Pre-Intubation and Intubation Medications
documents.indications: • Intubation attempts
documents.contraindications:
• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• See specific contraindications for medications below
documents.treatment: It is expected that in virtually ALL circumstances the Paramedic will patch to the TMP prior to performing a Rapid Sequence Intubation or Sedation Facilitated Intubation (SFI) (see mandatory patch points below) but it is recognized that there may be rare circumstances in which a patient requires immediate intubation with sedation/dissociation and a timely patch cannot be completed. In this circumstance utilize the medication guidelines below to perform the intubation and patch as soon as possible.
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• RSI intubation falls under the CCP and ACP(f) scope
• If patient requires recurrent doses of phenylephrine to maintain adequate MAP consult the TMP</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Lidocaine (Xylocaine) Spray
dose_route:
<center>10 mg/spray onto the pharynx, hypopharynx
MAX cumulative dose of 5 mg/kg or 400 mg</center>
drug_cards.notes: *Consider Lidocaine for oro-tracheal facilitated and awake intubations

drug_cards.section: For Sedation Choose only one sedative agent +/- analgesic KETAMINE IS THE PREFERRED AGENT IN THE MAJORITY OF PATIENTS
drug_cards.title: Ketamine
Midazolam
dose_route:
<center>0.1 mg/kg IV (to a MAX of 8 mg
contraindicated if MAP < 80
<b>Titrating doses (up to the above doses) in potentially difficult airway for awake intubation (1-2 mg every 3-5 minutes)</center>

drug_cards.title: Propofol
drug_cards.notes:
CAUTION:
• Respiratory apnea and hypotension may occur with rapid induction 
• Avoid in elderly or hypovolemia or poor cardiovascular reserve
• Phenylephrine should be used to support BP if hypotension occurs
• Should be avoided in hypotension with head injury

drug_cards.title: Fentanyl (Sublimaze)
drug_cards.notes: Avoid or reduced titrated dosage (25-50 microgram IV every 3-5 minutes) if elderly, decreased level of consciousness, or maximally sympathetically stimulated and poor cardiovascular reserve

drug_cards.section: For Paralysis ROCURONIUM IS THE PREFERRED PARALYTIC IN THE MAJORITY OF PATIENTS
drug_cards.title: Rocuronium (Zemuron)
Succinylcholine (Anectine)
drug_cards.notes:
Contraindicated With:
<tab1>• Malignant hyperthermia
• Hyperkalemia (known or concern)
• Myopathies/Muscular dystrophies
• Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, Multiple Sclerosis
• Guillain-Barre Syndrome, botulism
• Burns ≥ 2nd degree over 10% BSA > 24 hours until healed
• Stroke with hemiparesis, spinal cord injury > 72 hours until 6 months post injury
• Severe intra-abdominal sepsis > 72 hours until resolution</tab1>

drug_cards.section: Treatment of Hypotension associated with Sedation
drug_cards.title: Phenylephrine (Neosynephrine)
dose_route: MAP < 65 MAP < 80 (high ICP, ischemic stroke or spinal cord injury) 100 micrograms IV/IO q 3 minutes prn MAX 3 doses (300 micrograms)

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin) 10 mcg/ml - 1:100 000
dose_route:
<center>5-20 mcg IV/IO q 2-5 minutes PRN
Target MAP >65</center>

documents.title: Adult - Transport of Tracheostomy Patient
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Patient with existing tracheostomy requiring transport.
• Assume all patients with tracheostomy have a difficult airway and prepare accordingly</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable.</tab1>
documents.clinical: <tab1>• Qualified staff as identified in the flow chart is defined as someone who is competent, equipped and prepared to perform a surgical airway in the event of tracheostomy disaster.</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Transport of Patient with Tracheostomy
dose_route:
<center>PCP transport may be considered if:
Chronic tracheostomy AND
Self-managed by patient or family with no nursing care required</center>

drug_cards.title: Transport of Patient with Trachesotomy
dose_route: <center>Follow tracheostomy transport process outlines in flow chart</center>

documents.title: Adult - Emergency Tracheostomy Tube Reinsertion
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Patient with existing tracheostomy where the inner and/or outer cannula(s) have been removed from the airway;
AND
• Respiratory distress
AND
• Inability to adequately ventilate</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Inability to landmark or visualize</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Risk is much higher on reinsertion of tube into tracheostomy, cricothyrotomy, or laryngectomy site when less than 7 days since creation. Reinsertion may create a false passage with subcutaneous emphysema and fatal hypoxia due to inability to secure the airway
• Risk is higher if tube placed for airway obstruction, difficult airway, or laryngectomy (due to inability to manage airway from above)
• At minimum always bring a spare inner cannula which is size and type (disposable or reusable) specific for patient’s tracheostomy tube
• At minimum, a complete spare tracheostomy tube one size smaller should be available during transport
• Ensure tracheostomy ties are snug (i.e. can only fit two fingers between the tie and the patient’s neck) prior to transport
• A reinsertion attempt is defined as the insertion of the cannula into the tracheostomy replacing the inner and/or outer cannula with a new one is preferred over cleaning and reusing an existing one
NOTE: Please refer to the matrix below on the next page.</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Consider Emergency Tracheostomy Tube Reinsertion
dose_route:
<center>The Maximum number of attempts is 2

If unable to replace, initiate BVM from above
Requires occlusion of the stoma with palm of hand, tegaderm or occlusive dressing</center>

<center>If cannot re-insert existing tracheostomy tube or re-insert an alternate tracheostomy tube
Place cuffed ETT 6.0 or smaller over bougie through patient stoma site
Confirm with ETC02 and clinical indicators</center>

documents.title: Adult - Bronchoconstriction
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Respiratory distress AND
• Suspected bronchoconstriction</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Allergy to peanuts (i.e. Ipratropium Bromide (Atrovent))</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• MDI delivery systems require 45 seconds to “re-charge” between doses. Not waiting the recommended length of time between doses will result in significantly decreased amounts of medication being delivered/activation
• In the event of a respiratory outbreak as identified by originating facility / Ornge, the MDI must be used instead of nebulization
• Side effects of Magnesium Sulfate include hypotension; monitor BP closely</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Salbutamol (Ventolin) MDI (100 microgram/puff)
dose_route:
<center>8 puffs
(45 seconds between each administration)
may repeat x 3 q 5-15 minutes prn</center>

drug_cards.title: Salbutamol (Ventolin) Solution Via Nebulized Aerosol (2.5 mg/2.5 mL)
drug_cards.notes: *Total volume of Salbutamol and Normal Saline should be 3 mL

drug_cards.title: Ipratropium Bromide (Atrovent) MDI (20 microgram/puff)
dose_route:
<center>5 puffs
(45 seconds between each administration)
may repeat x 3 every 15 minutes prn
MAX 3 doses</center>

drug_cards.title: Ipratropium Bromide (Atrovent) Solution< Via Nebulized Aerosol (250 mg/mL)
dose_route:
<center>500 micrograms q 15 minutes x 3 prn
MAX 3 doses</center>
drug_cards.notes: *Total volume of Ipratropium Bromide (Atrovent) and Normal Saline should be 3 mL

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin)
drug_cards.notes: Use with caution when history of coronary artery disease or stroke

drug_cards.title: Dexamethasone
drug_cards.notes: *No IV/IO for PCP

drug_cards.title: Magnesium Sulfate
dose_route:
<center>2 g (4 mL)/100 mL
Administer over 15 minutes</center>

documents.title: Adult - Thoracostomy - Needle
documents.indications: • Severe respiratory distress in the setting of chest trauma with hemodynamic compromise AND/OR • Traumatic VSAs AND/OR • Severe hemodynamic compromise during positive pressure ventilation particularly in trauma or asthma or COPD patients AND/OR • Chest trauma, Severe Asthma or COPD, hemodynamic compromise and one or more of the following: ◦ Decreased/absent breath sounds on affected side ◦ Cyanosis ◦ JVD ◦ Hyper resonance on affected side ◦ Tracheal shift (late sign)
documents.contraindications: • Not applicable
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• The patient must be seen as soon as possible at an appropriate facility for the insertion of chest tube(s)
• Consider differential diagnosis:
</tab1><tab2>◦ Main stem intubation
◦ Pleural effusion
◦ Hemothorax
◦ Consolidated pneumonia
◦ Auto PEEP
◦ Dynamic hyperinflation</tab2>

dose_route: Consider differential diagnosis and decompress if high probability of tension pneumothorax

documents.title: Adult - Maintenance of Chest Tubes
documents.indications: • Initiated by sending facility
documents.contraindications: • Not applicable
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• A Heimlich flutter valve may be adequate if no drainage system has been implemented
• Suction beyond -20 cm H2O requires patch authorization prior to transport</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Maintain chest drainage systems during call to keep the drainage system clear
dose_route: If the patient’s chest tube was maintained by suction at the sending facility, the Paramedic may maintain suction to no greater than -20 cm H2O
If the patient’s chest tube was maintained by gravity drainage, the Paramedic may maintain by gravity drainage to underwater seal or to suction as per patient presentation

documents.title: Adult - Initiating or Maintaining Mechanical Ventilation
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Need for mechanical ventilation
• Hypoxemic respiratory failure
• Hypercapnic respiratory failure
• Mixed hypoxemic hypercapnic respiratory failure
• ETI airway management for transport</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
documents.treatment: All mechanically ventilated patients should be managed using standard settings with 'goal-directed ventilation orders' • CCPs may initiate and maintain mechanical ventilation without patching for patients who are intubated/ventilated for airway protection/patency; or patients with mild-to-moderate respiratory failure that do not require high levels of mechanical ventilation support • CCPs are not required to patch if they can achieve the following: o Ventilation goals: • SpO2 94-98% (88-92% if known CO2 retainer and this is target SpO2 at sending facility) • ETCO2 35-45 (or 33-38 if increased ICP) o Using mechanical ventilation settings within the following safety parameters: • Vt 6-8 ml/kg IBW (target Vt must be calculated and documented in ePCR) • Frequency of 10-20 breaths per minute • FiO2 0.6 or less • PEEP range 5-10 • Peak and plateau pressure less than or equal to 30 cm H20 • I:E ratio range 1:1.5-3.0 • Contraindications to CCP initiation and maintenance of mechanical ventilation without patch include: o Sending facility ventilation settings outside of safety parameters above • Exception: If FiO2 at sending facility higher than 0.6, CCP medics may attempt brief weaning trial prior to departing sending facility and if able to wean to 0.6 and achieve oxygen saturation 94-98% patch not required o Inability to maintain mechanical ventilation goals without exceeding safety parameters above o Use of oxygenation adjuncts at sending facility such as inhaled heliox, nitric oxide, inhaled Flolan or prone positioning o Serum bicarbonate (from ABG/VBG/electrolytes) < 15 or > 35 (need to clarify pH/ETCO2 target with TMP) • CCPs may use AC Pressure Control ventilation or Volume Control ventilation to achieve mechanical ventilation goals for patients requiring controlled ventilation with guaranteed rate/minute ventilation; for patients spontaneously breathing consider Pressure Support ventilation* (potential benefit of decreased need for sedation) • ACP(f)s MUST patch prior to initiating or maintaining ventilation in ALL patients. • All paramedics should plan to ventilate patients utilizing the treatment guidelines below. • When mechanical ventilation is initiated, all settings and patient’s response to treatment must be documented on the Call Report. The patient’s end tidal CO2, O2 saturation levels, RRtotal, Vt, FiO2, PEEP and PIPs must be continuously monitored and recorded *Pressure Support Ventilation (PSV) on the LTV 1200 is achieved by setting the ventilator to Pressure + SIMV/CPAP + Breath Rate to zero (--).
documents.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

drug_cards.section: Assessment and Preparation of the Ventilated Patient
dose_route:
Confirm ETT placement (ETCO2 & Auscultation) and ETT depth at least 21 cm at the lips in females and 23 cm at the lips in males.
Check ETT cuff pressure 20-30 cm H2O.
Obtain baseline vital signs.
Choose mode of ventilation for patient:
<tab1>• PSV if awake & spontaneously breathing;
• AC with either PCV or VC if inadequate respirations, heavily sedated or high ventilator settings required.</tab1>
Perform leak test on ventilator circuit.
Calculate and document on the call report the ideal body weight based on measured height/gender table*
<tab1>• IBW in kg for females = 45.5 + 2.3 x [height in inches-60]
• IBW in kg for males = 50 + 2.3 x [height in inches-60]</tab1>
May use measured height from sending facility to calculate if available.
Review most recent chest film and arterial blood gas if available, and confirm ETT in good position as per sending facility CXR or sending MD or radiology report; document confirmation:
<tab1>• If unable to confirm ETT position with CXR as above consider delay time to obtain CXR versus clinical impact to patient in delayed transport</tab1>Document ETT size and depth at the lips.Confirm serum bicarbonate level from electrolytes, ABG or VBG (require ETCO2 target adjustment if HCO3 < 15 or > 35).Determine if patient has the following:
<tab1>• Normal lung physiology
• COPD/Asthma
• Lung Injury/ARDS
• Severe Metabolic Acidosis</tab1></left>

Start Assist Control Adjust pressure control or set volume to achieve Vt 6-8 ml/kg. Frequency 10-20/min to achieve ETCO2 of 35-45 mm Hg unless increased ICP= ETC02 33-38. Initiate FiO2 at 1.0 or match FiO2 from sending facility if available, wean FiO2 to keep SpO2 94-98%. Minimum PEEP of 5 for all patients, may increase up to 10 if required to match sending facility ventilator setting or to achieve O2 saturation target. Titrate FiO2 and PEEP to achieve O2 sat 94-98% target (88-92% if known CO2 retainer and matches target at sending facility). Adjust inspiratory time to achieve I:E ratio between 1:1.5 and 1:3.0 (may use longer I time to improve mean airway pressure and subsequently oxygenation, shorter I time if obstructive airway disease). Adjust sensitivity to trigger with respiratory effort (default is 3 lpm). PIP < 30 cm H20. Plateau < 30 cm H20. DeltaP (PPlat - PEEP) < 15 cm H2O If already well ventilated, consider maintaining current setting. Ensure BVM with external PEEP valve and manometer available for duration of transport. Target ETCO2 35-45 unless increased ICP + ETCO2 33-38 Target Vt to 6-8 mL/kg IBW. Adjust PSV/PCV (or set Vt in VC) to obtain Vt target. Adjust RR 10-20 to achieve target ETCO2 once target Vt obtained. NOTE: minimum PSV 8 cm H2O. Chronically ventilated patients may have PSV as low as 5/5 provided tidal volume according to IBW is maintained. Must maintain plateau/peak airway pressure < 30 cm H20 with adjustments.
Alarm Guidelines
Set High pressure 5-10 cm H20 above the PIP. Set Low pressure alarm 5-10 cm H20 below PIP. Set minute ventilation alarm at 75% of actual VE.

<left>Record and monitor the following ventilator parameters:
<tab1>• Target Vt/IBW
• Pressure or Volume control
• AC/SIMV/PSV
• Sensitivity
• Frequency
• Tidal volume
• Minute ventilation
• PEEP
• Pressure support
• Inspiratory time
• I:E ratio
• ETCO2
• FiO2
• Peak Inspiratory Pressure
• Mean Airway Pressure</tab1></left>

<left>Monitor ETCO2 and capnographic waveforms throughout transport.
Monitor mean arterial pressure changes related to potential ventilator changes during transport.
Consider checking plateau pressure and/or auto PEEP if concerned about lung compliance or air trapping. NOTE: to perform either maneuver requires an apneic patient

Maximum cuff pressure = 20-30 cm H2O OR Minimum Occluding Volume (MOV) - inflate until you hear no leak at PIP Tracheal perfusion pressure = 30mmHg (arterial) / 18mmHg (venous) Recommended cuff pressure is just enough to seal the trachea at PIP/MOV. Check cuff pressure using a manometer. Palpating the pilot balloon is not an acceptable determination of cuff pressure.

To prevent or treat autoPEEP Use low to normal frequency (8-12 breaths/min). Titrate frequency to maximize I:E ratio > 1:4 – 1:5 allowing for long expiratory time. Use low tidal volume 4-6 mL/kg of ideal body weight. PEEP 5 cm H2O Adjust inspiratory time < 1.0 second (0.7-1.0). Keep Plateau Pressure < 30 cm H20. Titrate parameters to achieve Sp02 91%-94% or in keeping with patient’s baseline status.

Severe airway obstruction may not allow complete expiration prior to the next delivered breath. Severe airway obstruction may result in PIPs > 30 cm H2O to achieve target Vt 4-6 ml/kg IBW
Intrinsic or autoPEEP develops, leading to worsening hypoxia, hypercapnea and hypotension.
Monitor capnographic waveform for sloped expiratory rise indicating airflow obstruction.
Consider Salbutamol & Ipratropium Bromide via MDI.
If Difficult to ventilate or oxygenate consider: Permissive hypercapnia Consider matching auto-PEEP; i.e. set PEEP to 2-3 cm H2O < then measured autoPEEP

<tab1>• Consider use of Magnesium Sulfate IV infusion
• Consider Ketamine IV infusion
• Consider paralysis
• Optimize analgosedation and paralysis in combination with above therapies</tab1>

Initial frequency 20-26/min. Adjust to maintain target ETCO2.
Initial Vt 6 mL/kg. Adjust Vt based on plateau pressures:
<tab1>• If plateau > 30 cmH20 then decrease Vt to 4-5 ml/kg
• If plateau < 30 cmH20 then Vt may be increased to maximum 8 ml/kg</tab1>
Start with FIO2 of 1.0 and PEEP of 5-8 cm H20<tab1>• If SpO2 >98% then decrease FIO2;
• If SpO2 < 90% then increase PEEP to 10 and then incrementally by 2 cm H20 to maximum of 20.Refer to the ARDSnet PEEP/FiO2 table</tab1>
Check tidal volume with every adjustmentmadeto pressure control and PEEPsettings. Watch for drop in Vt indicating potential excessive PEEP).
VC: Check peak/ plateau pressure with every change in PEEP and tidal volume.
Keep plateau pressure < 30 cm H20.
Keep Driving Pressure (DeltaP, Plat-PEEP) < 15 cm H2O
Minimize FIO2 ideally < 0.60.
Adjust PEEP ideally above lower inflection point and/or to achieve SpO2 > 92%.
Allow for permissive hypercapnia.
ETCO2 45-80 mm Hg (based on ABG target pH 7.20-7.25).</left>

Inflamed lungs with decreased compliance and increased dead space are prone to atelectasis, barotrauma and volutrauma. Do not decrease tidal volumes below 4 mL/kg Increased I:E ratio can improve oxygenation by increasing mean airway pressure and helping to maintain PEEP. I:E ratio’s < 1:2 should be considered. For example: • 1:1.8 • 1:1.6 • 1:1.4 • 1:1.2 • 1:1.0

drug_cards.title: Simplified table (minimum target PEEP for increased FiO2)
drug_cards.notes: Use this table for guidance when addressing ongoing hypoxia and increasing oxygenation support, do not use for initial ventilator settings

documents.title: Adult - Lung Volume Recruitment (LVR)
documents.clinical:
Hamilton T1 Lung Volume Recruitment Maneuver (LRM)
 1. With ventilation in the current mode, open the Mode screen and select APRV then hit Confirm to open the controls screen. 2. Set P high 30 cm H2O and T high to 30 seconds. 3. P low will be the same as the current PEEP cm H2O, … add + 2 cmH2O which establishes post LRM PEEP in the original mode as well. 4. Open 'Apnea' screen and turn off apnea back-up ventilation a. Note that if you need to perform a repeat LRM, the vent will remember APRV Pressure and Time settings, however the apnea back-up will revert to “ON”. Remember to turn this off each time. 5. Hit “Confirm” to start the maneuver. 6. As the vent switches to APRV, watch the Pressure/Time curve. The pressure should be at 30 cmH2O. If it is lower, hit the 'Manual breath' button to end the current APRV breath and force a new one at the P high level 30 cm H2O. 7. As soon as you’ve confirmed that the LRM is working at 30 cmH2O, open the Mode screen, select the previous mode and hit Confirm. a. All the control settings will be retained and the PEEP will now reflect the PEEP you set in the APRV mode. b. Hit Confirm again. Don’t delay this step. This will allow: i. you to abort the LRM if indicated by simply activating a manual breath ii. the vent to automatically switch back to the desired mode at the APRV 30 second mark 8. The vent will stay in APRV at the P high level until the next breath cycle (i.e. 30 seconds). With the next breath the vent will resume ventilation in the previous mode.

documents.title: Adult - Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NPPV)
documents.indications: <tab1>• Conscious patient able to protect airway in respiratory distress</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• NPPV is contraindicated in patients with active vomiting and in those that are unable to manage airway secretions
• Decreased level of consciousness/severe agitation
• Inability to protect airway
• Repeated hemoptysis
• Cardiac arrest or respiratory arrest
• Immediate need for endotracheal intubation
• Upper airway obstruction
• Facial trauma
• Recent esophagostomy</tab1>
<title>Relative Contraindications</title>
<tab1>• Hemodynamic instability</tab1>
documents.clinical: • Patch first if the patient has altered mentation or is lethargic • NIPPV may be of benefit in hypercarbia from ventilatory failure even with altered mental status • For agitated patients consider TMP discussion for sedation Understanding the numbers • iPAP = Inspiratory Positive Airway Pressure (Peak inspiratory pressure - PIP). iPAP is the sum of PEEP and PS; e.g. if the PEEP = 5 and you set a PS of 10, the resultant iPAP = 15 • ePAP = Expiratory Positive Airway Pressure (PEEP) • Pressure Support = the difference between iPAP & ePAP • CPAP = when iPAP equals ePAP (example: CPAP 5=PS 0/PEEP 5)

drug_cards.title: Initiation of CPAP/NPPV
dose_route: Initial Settings iPAP 10 cmH2O/ePAP 5 cm H2O MAX iPAP 20 cmH2O/ePAP 10 cmH2O

drug_cards.title: Maintenance of NIPPV Initiated By Sending Facility
dose_route: <center>Patient's hemodynamics and ventilation status stable on current settings</center>

documents.title: Adult - High Flow Nasal Cannula Therapy (HFNC)
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Refractory hypoxemia despite optimized conventional nasal cannula and/or non-rebreather mask O2 therapy in individuals with an intact, acceptable respiratory drive
</tab1><tab2>o Adults: SpO2 <90%</tab2><tab1>
• COPD/CHF exacerbation requiring a minimal amount of PEEP
• Palliative respiratory support with no endotracheal intubation or non-invasive ventilation (NIV) support in the care plan</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• A definitive airway is required for airway protection and/or respiratory support characterized by acute respiratory acidosis
• Complete nasal airway obstruction
• Use with caution if there is a history of facial trauma, acute sinusitis or otitis
</tab1><title>Complications</title><tab1>
• Unmeasured PEEP may result in pneumothorax or lung hyperinflation</tab1>
documents.clinical:
• Prior to transport perform a 10 minute trial period off HFNC, using a NRB + conventional NC to determine patient tolerance when AC power is not available for HFNC; e.g. transfer between ambulance and hospital. A successful trial is confirmed by patient SpO2 ≥ 88%. If battery power is not a concern, there is no requirement to conduct this trial.
• In consultation with the TMP, HFNC may be considered as an adjunct to actively rewarm hypothermic patients.

documents.title: Adult - Transport of Patients in the Prone Position

<title>General Principles:</title>
<tab1>• Mechanically ventilate as per Ornge Clinical Practice Guidelines for ARDS
• Maintain Sedation and Analgesia as per Ornge Sedation and Pain Management of Ventilated Patients Guidelines to target a sedation score of -4 (i.e., deep sedation)
• Maintain paralysis during transport (see below)</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<title>Cardiac Arrest in Prone Position</title><tab1>
• In the event of cardiac arrest, if the rhythm is shockable, defibrillation should be initiated immediately. Ensure defibrillation pads are applied in an anterior-posterior orientation prior to initiating transport.
• CPR will be performed in the prone position and the paramedic team should not attempt to return the patient supine to do chest compressions.
• The decision of transporting a prone patient will be made in conjunction with the TMP, sending physician, and/or receiving physician and the best attempt made to inform the substitute decision maker of the risks and limitations of the transport.</tab1>

documents.title: Pain Scale For Adult Intubated Patients
content: Presence of frowning, brow lowering, orbit tightening and levator contraction
All of the facial movements plus eyelid tightly closed
Does not move at all (does not necessarily mean absence of pain)
Slow, cautious movements, touching or rubbing the pain site, seeking attention through movements
Pulling tube, attempting to sit up, moving limbs/thrashing, not following commands, striking at staff, trying to climb out of bed
Muscle tension: Evaluated by passive flexion and extension of upper extremities
Strong resistance to passive movements, inability to complete them
Compliance with the ventilator (intubated patients) OR Vocalization (extubated patients)
Asynchrony: blocking ventilation, alarms frequently activated
Talking in normal tone or no sound
Talking in normal tone or no sound

documents.title: Sedation Scale For Adults (RASS Score)
content: Tolerating ventilator mostly; needs sedation and analgesia when stimulated and moved
Tolerating ventilator mostly; needs sedation and analgesia when stimulated and moved
Wakes < 10s; Eye contact; Simple commands only
Tolerating ventilator mostly; needs sedation and analgesia when stimulated and moved
Reaches for ETT, mild distress, coughing
Moves to voice; no eye contact
Coughing when moved but tolerates ventilation otherwise
Pupils dilated, ↑↑HR or ↑↑BP with external stimulation (1)
No response to voice; Moves spontaneously and to physical stimuli
Minimal or no reaction (pupils, HR, BP) with stimulation (1)
Minimal or no response to voice or noxious stimuli
Minimal or no response to ventilator
Minimal or no reaction (pupils, HR, BP) with stimulation (1)

documents.treatment: Infusions are preferred to repeat bolus dosing for sedation and analgesia wherever possible. documents.clinical:
<tab1>• In patients with known difficult airways, muscle relaxation is strongly recommended post intubation to ensure minimal risk for loss of ETT in transport
• Complete history and physical examination (including baseline neurologic assessment) must be completed
• Baseline assessment of vital signs and level of paralysis should be obtained and documented to detect and record the patient’s subsequent response to paralysis
• Muscle relaxants will hide the motor component of seizures. In cases of status epilepticus or risk of seizures, use paralysis as a last resort and in conjunction with anticonvulsant/sedative infusions. Monitor for autonomic manifestations of seizures
• Proper securing of the ETT is paramount</tab1>

documents.title: Contraindications to Thrombolytics
content: Any prior intracranial hemorrhage, hemorrhagic stroke, or stroke of unknown origin
Known structural cerebral vascular lesion (i.e. arteriovenous malformation)
Active bleeding or bleeding diathesis (excluding menses)
Gastrointestinal bleeding within the last month
Major trauma/surgery/head injury within three months
<b>* Must be 'No' to all Absolute Criteria to proceed
Patient within 90 minutes of PCI centre from scene, consider direct transport for PCI OR 120 minutes from PCI centre if in a community hospital
History of chronic, severe, poorly controlled hypertension
Severe uncontrolled hypertension on presentation (SBP greater than 180 mmHg or DBP > than 110 mmHg)†
History of prior ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack within six months, dementia, or known intracranial pathology not covered in contraindications
Traumatic or prolonged CPR (> than ten minutes)
Recent internal bleeding (within two to four weeks)
Pregnancy or within one week postpartum
Current use of anticoagulants: the higher the INR, the higher the risk of bleeding
* Must have this information available for the TMP to help weigh risk/benefit of thrombolytic therapy
†Could be an absolute contraindication in low-risk patients with MI

documents.title: Adult - Care of Patients with Left Ventricular Assist Device (LVAD)
documents.indications: <tab1>• Transport and management of the patient with LVAD</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
documents.clinical: Background o Left ventricular assist devices (LVADs) use an impeller that propels blood from the left ventricle to the aorta. o LVADs are used for patient with heart failure as a bridge therapy or as a destination therapy in patients with heart failure. o Given the complexity of the device, and potential complications for patients with LVAD devices, a minimum ACP(f) level of care should be considered for patients with conditions that are not cardiac related and CCP level of care should be considered for cardiac patients, device specific concerns, and/or unstable patients (e.g., septic patients). o LVAD patients are well supported by VAD centres with patient and device specific algorithms. General Management o If a patient with LVAD is identified, paramedics should make every attempt to pre-patch with the TMP to obtain more information about the device. The TMP should attempt to contact the patient’s VAD centre for clinical guidance. o Perform 12-lead ECG to identify dysrhythmias. o If a loud alarm is heard from the controller, assume LVAD failure and troubleshoot the battery/controller. o LVAD patients do not typically have a palpable peripheral pulse. o Blood pressure measurement will require either auscultation or doppler to identify the MAP. The goal is to keep the MAP between 60 and 90 mm Hg. To measure the blood pressure, inflate the cuff to above 120 mm Hg then slowly deflate until an audible flow is detected over the brachial artery. This will be your MAP reading. o Have an extremely LOW threshold to request sending facility place an arterial line. • Arterial line enables most accurate MAP measurement, provides access for labs to guide resuscitation, and contributes to assessing CPR quality if indicated. o If the patient is unresponsive, and ventricular dysrhythmia is detected, proceed with cardioversion. If the patient is responsive and ventricular dysrhythmia is detected, contact TMP prior to treating. o Assess for LVAD related complications: § GI Bleed § Infection § Stroke § Suction events § Pump thrombosis § Ventricular arrhythmias § RV Failure § Aortic regurgitation • LVAD ABCs AAuscultate for mechanical LVAD hum; No hum = Not working B Battery Status – - controller low battery alarm? - Plugged into mobile power unit or - Connected to functioning batteries? C Controller - Assess for controller alarms - Is the controller malfunctioning, necessitating exchange? D Driveline – is driveline connected to controller and intact? E Echocardiogram – If available perform cardiac POCUS to assess for reversible causes of hemodynamic instability and cardiac arrest
documents.treatment:
• Paramedics are required to perform LVAD specific Assessments, including:
<tab1>o All patients MUST have a blood pressure and 12-lead ECG documented</tab1>
<tab1>o Check LVAD Controller and batteries</tab1>
<tab1>o Identify the patient’s VAD centre</tab1>
<tab1>o Obtain IV access</tab1>
<tab1>o Assess and manage patient ABCs and then LVAD ABCs</tab1>
<tab2>• Approach airway and breathing similarly to any patient in extremis
• Recall pulse oximetry is completely unreliable without pulsatile flow
• Circulation assessment is difficult given typical absence of pulses and difficulty establishing an MAP
• Refer to Table for LVAD ABCs considerations
</tab2><tab1>• For patients presenting extremis - trouble shoot the LVAD first
• LVAD patients in cardiac arrest with a non-functional LVAD should be treated with standard ACLS including CPR and defibrillation</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Primary Non-Cardiac Issue in LVAD Patient
dose_route:
<center>ACP LOC can be used to transport stable LVAD patients with other non-cardiac medical issues(e.g., orthopedic injuries)
PATCH to TMP prior to departing from facility, if possible.</center>

drug_cards.title: Unstable and/or Primary Cardiac Issue in LVAD Patient
dose_route:
<center>CCP LOC is required to transfer unstable patients or patients with primary cardiac issue (e.g., worsening heart failure, dysrhythmias, ICD malfunction, and septic shock).
PATCH to TMP prior to departing from facility, if possible.</center>

documents.title: Adult - Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump (IABP) Auxiliary Medical Directive
documents.indications:
<tab1>• A CCP may provide the treatment prescribed in this auxiliary medical directive if certified and authorized
• Patient > 18 years old
• Patient > 40 kg
• Patient must already be on Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump (IABP) at the sending hospital</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
documents.treatment:
<tab1>• Paramedics are required to perform IABP specific assessments
</tab1><tab2>o Verify balloon position and size
o Identify balloon tip on x-ray
o Assess for distal pulses in insertion limb
o Assess for urine output
o Identify if catheter is fiber optic
o Identify trigger being used
o Assess IABP waveform
o Ensure catheter is sutured securely in place</tab2>
Paramedics are required to Patch to obtain orders when providing IABP care.
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• 1 IABP certified paramedic with CCP partner
• Paramedics are not permitted to advance or remove IABP catheters
• Paramedics are required to ensure transport IABP is in ready state, fully charged, appropriate helium levels, paper role, and appropriate cables
• Document sending facility IABP parameters</tab1>

dose_route:
<tab1><left>• Both paramedics at the bedside for transition to transport IABP
• Put IABP in 1:2 ratio
• Select trigger
• Assess and adjust 3 rules of timing to achieve ideal waveform and augmentation
• Run a recording strip
• Maintain head of bed no higher than 30 degrees
• Keep insertion limb straight
• Ensure no blood is present in the catheter
• Return IABP ratio to 1:1 or 1:2 matching setting from sending</left></tab1>

<tab1><left>• Exercise caution to protect IABP catheter from being pulled.
• Continuously monitor the patient and the performance of the IABP, make adjustments as required to maintain good augmentation
• Run a recorder strip at the start of transport and again at the end of transport
• Plug IABP into vehicle power source to conserve IABP internal battery</left></tab1>

<tab1><left>• Paramedics to ensure safe transfer of IABP care with accepting hospital staff
• Run final strip prior to transfer
• Document as required on ACR among other care the specifics of the IABP</left></tab1>

documents.title: Adult - Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) Auxiliary Medical Directive
documents.indications:
<tab1>• A CCP may provide the treatment prescribed in this auxiliary medical directive if certified and authorized</tab1>
<tab1>• Accompanied by ECMO team including ECMO physician</tab1>
<tab1>• Age ≥ 16</tab1>
<tab1>• Veno-venous (VV) or Veno-arterial (VA) Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO)/Extracorporeal Life Support (ECLS)</tab1>
<tab1>• Successful cannula placement and ECMO initiation</tab1>
<tab1>• Authorized crews transporting without an ECMO physician MUST complete a 3-way patch with the ECMO receiving facility Most Responsible Physician (MRP) and the Ornge TMP prior to transport</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Minimum 1 ECMO certified paramedic with CCP partner
• The CCP must patch with the TMP if medications or dosing parameters are required beyond those provided for in this ECMO Auxiliary Medical Directives; or in the case of ECMO failure requiring use of emergency medical directives (as soon as practical and safe to do so taking into account workload to stabilize patient)
• The CCP may also provide all additional care covered by routine CCP level medical directives</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Mechanical ventilation*
dose_route:
<tab1>• Pressure Control Ventilation
• RR 10 breaths/min**
• Pressure control 10 cmH20**
• PEEP 10 cmH20**
• FiO2 0.3
• Protective lung strategy Vt 4-5 ml/kg IBW, RR 10/min, Ti 1.0 sec</tab1>

** or to an initial maximum of 20-20-20 (RR-PC-PEEP) as requested by the ECMO physician

Keep plateau pressures less than 30 cm H20 with adjustments unless ECMO failure (see ECMO failure emergency medical directives)
May titrate FiO2 up to 1.0 and PEEP up to 20 if requested by ECMO physician
 Given that PaCO2 and PaO2 determined by ECMO rather than mechanical ventilation, there is no need to titrate mechanical ventilation during transport (please refer to the Emergency Medical Directive for ECMO/ECLS Failure portion at the end of the Medical Directive for orders in the event of ECMO failure)
drug_cards.notes: *Confirm ETT placement on chest X-ray from sending facility

drug_cards.section: Circulatory / Cardiac Support Continue any of the following medications being administered at the time of initiation of ECMO and/or add/titrate at the request of the ECMO physician within the prescribed ranges below. Match dose from sending facility as starting dose.
drug_cards.title: Norepinephrine (Levophed)
dose_route:
<center>0-0.5 microgram/kg/min IV
Match sending facility for starting dose
Target MAP > 65</center>

drug_cards.title: Vasopressin
dose_route:
<center>0.02-0.1 units/min IV
Match sending facility for starting dose
Target MAP > 65</center>

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine Target MAP > 65
dose_route:
<center>0-0.5 microgram/kg/min
Match sending facility for starting dose</center>
drug_cards.notes:
*to prepare push-dose EPINEPHrine (i.e., 10 microgram/mL concentration)
<tab1>1. Draw 100 microgram (i.e. 1 mL of 1:10,000) EPINEPHrine and dilute in 9 mL of Normal Saline</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Phenylephrine Target MAP > 65
dose_route:
<center>0-500 microgram/min
Match sending facility for starting dose</center>

drug_cards.title: DOBUTamine
dose_route:
<center>5-20 microgram/kg/min IV/IO
Initiate at 5 microgram/kg/min
Titrate by 2.5mcg/kg/min increments, q 10 minutes PRN
Minimum MAP 60 prior to initiating</center>

drug_cards.title: Milirinone
dose_route:
<center>0.125-0.25 microgram/kg/min IV
Match sending facility for starting dose
Target MAP >65</center>

drug_cards.title: Amiodarone
dose_route:
<center>1-4 mg/min IV
Match sending facility for starting dose
Target MAP >65</center>

drug_cards.title: Fluids
dose_route:
<center>Bolus 20 mL/kg RL or NS q 15 minutes prn to keep MAP > 65 and/or if rising vasopressor requirements
Assess for signs of fluid overload between each bolus and hold further fluid boluses if signs fluid overload
May substitute sodium bicarbonate (3 amps in 850 cc D5W) instead of NS/RL as bolus fluid 20 ml/kg at request of ECMO physician for metabolic acidosis</center>

<center>Maintenance infusion RL or NS at 0-150 cc/hr (choice as per ECMO physician and/or to match sending facility, RL preferred)
May switch to sodium bicarbonate infusion (3 amps in 850 mL D5W) at 0-150 cc/hr</center>

drug_cards.title: Red Blood Cells (RBC)
dose_route: <center>Transfuse RBC at request of ECMO physician if Hb < 70 g/L or if active bleeding; medics may bring RBC from sending facility to have on standby if available and requested by ECMO physician</center>

drug_cards.title: HYDROmorphone
dose_route:
<center>Maintenance of continuous IV infusion: 1-60 mcg/kg/hr
Usual dosage range: 500-3000 mcg/hr or 0.5-3 mg/hr</center>

drug_cards.title: Propofol (Diprivan
dose_route:
<center>1-5 mg/kg/hr
Titrate in increments of 0.3 mg/kg/hr q 5 minutes
prn if MAP > 70</center>

drug_cards.title: Cisatracurium
dose_route:
<center>0.1-0.2 mg/kg IV to initiate paralysis
0.03 mg/kg IV q 30 minutes prn</center>

<center>1-10 microgram/kg/min
(usual starting dose 3 microgram/kg/min after initiating paralysis)</center>

drug_cards.title: Rocuronium (Zemuron)
dose_route:
<center>0.6 mg/kg IV to initiate paralysis
0.3 mg/kg IV q 20 minutes</center>
drug_cards.notes: **Must have appropriate analgosedationbeingadministered at all times while paralyzed

drug_cards.section: Additional Medications At request of ECMO physician
drug_cards.title: Unfractionated Heparin
dose_route:
<center>60 units/kg IV bolus to MAX 5,000 units upon cannulation;
repeat as requested by ECMO physician/perfusionist</center>

<center>0-3000 units/hr IV, maintain dose from sending; adjust as requested by ECMO physician/perfusionist
APTTtarget 45-60 sec (refer to ACS medical directive for normogram)</center>

documents.title: Adult - Emergency Medical Directive for ECMO/ECLS Failure
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Cardiac Arrest
• ECMO/ECLS equipment failure
• Failure to Oxygenate
• Uncontrolled bleeding/Volume loss/Exsanguination</tab1>

drug_cards.section: May use all above ECMO medical directives, standard CCP Medical Directives, and in addition:
drug_cards.title: Mechanical ventilation
dose_route:
<tab1>• FiO2 1.0 and titrate down for O2 saturation > 95%
• PEEP 5-20, may increase settings to aim for Vt 6-8 ml/kg
• PIP < 30 (may increase to 40 if unable to achieve targets with settings otherwise)
• Titrate RR to achieve EtCO2 50-60 target
• I:E 1:1 if possible for oxygenation failure</tab1>
drug_cards.notes: **Mandatory TMP patch if ECMO failure as soon as possible after initiation of ECMO failure orders taking into account immediate patient care needs

drug_cards.title: ECMO Failure
dose_route:
<tab1>• Cardiac arrest
• ECMO/ECLS equipment failure
• Failure to oxygenate
• Uncontrolled bleeding/volume loss/exsanguination</tab1>

documents.title: Adult - Symptomatic Bradycardia
documents.indications: <tab1>• Symptomatic Bradycardia with a pulse</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Atropine
dose_route: <center>0.5 mg IV/IO initial dose (repeat q 3-5 minutes to max total dose 3 mg)</center>

drug_cards.title: Transcutaneous Cardiac Pacing
dose_route:
<center>Set pacing rate at 70
Start output at 10 milliamps (mA) and increase to achieve electrical capture with a pulse (mechanical capture)
Once mechanical capture has been confirmed increase mA by 10%
Confirm the presence of a pulse and assess blood pressure and perfusion</center>
drug_cards.notes: Patients with bradycardia requiring transcutaneous (TC) pacing who are conscious and aware of their surroundings may require sedation and analgesia prior to TC pacing. Below are directives for sedation and pain management for TCP. Patients that are peri-arrest can immediately receive TCP without sedation or analgesia

drug_cards.title: Procedural Sedation
dose_route: MAP ≥ 65 Ketamine 0.1 mg/kg, MAX 0.5 mg/kg OR Versed 0.05 mg/kg fentaNYL 1 micgrogram/kg

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin)
dose_route:
<center>0-0.5 microgram/kg/min IV/IO
Target MAP > 65
for MAP <50, initiate at min 0.3 mcg/kg/min and consider push dose EPINEPHrine</center>

documents.title: Adult - Transvenous Cardiac Pacing
documents.indications: <tab1>• Transvenous pacing, if initiated at the sending facility</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Monitor the cardiac rhythm and ensure the catheter/cable is carefully secured to prevent inadvertent tension or traction on the line
• Ideal capture threshold is < 1. High outputs are an indication of misplaced wires or more serious pathology that can be more prone to capture failure and need for TCP vs other interventions</tab1>

dose_route: Maintain transvenous pacing if initiated at sending facility (Initial pacing settings will reflect sending facility settings)
Any alteration of settings to be discussed with TMP

documents.title: Adult - Symptomatic Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Symptomatic Atrial Flutter
• Symptomatic Atrial Fibrillation</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.treatment: Patients with Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter where emergency synchronized cardioversion is indicated who are conscious and aware of their surroundings may require sedation and analgesia first. Below are medical directives for sedation and analgesia for cardioversion. Patients that are peri-arrest or hemodynamically unstable can be immediately managed with synchronized cardioversion without sedation or analgesia

drug_cards.title: Procedural Sedation
dose_route: MAP ≥ 65 Ketamine 0.1 mg/kg, MAX 0.5 mg/kg OR Versed 0.05 mg/kg fentaNYL 1 micgrogram/kg

documents.title: Adult - Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT)
documents.indications: <tab1>• Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT)</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.treatment: Patients with PSVT with a pulse who are conscious and aware of their surroundings may require sedation and analgesia prior to cardioversion. Below are directives for sedation and analgesia for cardioversion. Patients that are peri-arrest or hemodynamically unstable can be immediately cardioverted with synchronized cardioversion (without sedation or analgesia).
documents.clinical: <tab1>• Adenosine dose should be decreased if patient taking dipyridamole or carbamazepine, dose should be decreased if given by central line; caution in asthma</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Procedural Sedation
dose_route: MAP ≥ 65 Ketamine 0.1 mg/kg, MAX 0.5 mg/kg OR Versed 0.05 mg/kg fentaNYL 1 micgrogram/kg

drug_cards.title: Adenosine
dose_route:
<center>6 mg rapid IV/IO with 20 mL NS flush
Repeat at 12 mg x 1 prn</center>

documents.title: Adult - Ventricular Tachycardia with Perfusion
documents.indications: <tab1>• Ventricular Tachycardia (VT) with a pulse</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.treatment: Patients with VT with a pulse who are conscious and aware of their surroundings may require sedation and analgesia prior to cardioversion. Below are directives for sedation and analgesia for cardioversion. Patients that are peri-arrest or hemodynamically unstable can be immediately cardioverted with synchronized cardioversion without sedation or analgesia.
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Consider early Magnesium IV for polymorphic VT
• Polymorphic VT should prompt consideration if clinically appropriate for toxicologic exposure which have specific antidote therapies (Ex: Beta blockers in hydrocarbon toxicity). Emergent TMP consultation is indicated
• Consider hyperkalemia medical directive (167) for wide complex tachycardia/lethal arrythmias</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Procedural Sedation
dose_route: MAP ≥ 65 Ketamine 0.1 mg/kg, MAX 0.5 mg/kg OR Versed 0.05 mg/kg fentaNYL 1 micgrogram/kg

drug_cards.title: Amiodarone (Cordarone)
dose_route:
<center>150 mg IV over 10 minutes
(may repeat x1 as adjunct to cardioversion)</center>

documents.title: Adult - Intravenous Line Initiation
documents.indications: <tab1>• Actual or potential need for intravenous or fluid therapy</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Suspected fracture proximal to the IV site</tab1>
documents.clinical: <tab1>• *A PCP(f) may provide the treatment prescribed in this auxiliary medical directive if certified and authorized</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Initiate IV
dose_route: <center>MAX of 2 peripheral IV lines may be established</center>

documents.title: Adult - Intraosseous Initiation and Maintenance
documents.indications: • Inadequate intravenous access for resuscitation • Unable to obtain intravenous access after two (2) attempts or 90 seconds
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Known or suspected fracture, injury, deformity, or infection overlying the proposed insertion site
• Absence of adequate anatomic landmarks
• Previous IO insertion in the bone in the past 48 hours
• Known or suspected fracture of affected limb</tab1>
documents.clinical: <tab1>• Resuscitation indicates the process of correcting physiological disorders in the acutely unwell patient. The patient need not be in cardiac arrest to qualify for IO insertion</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate intervention based upon the presenting condition

documents.title: Adult - Intraosseous Vascular Access Analgesia
documents.indications: <tab1>• Patient requiring intraosseous (IO) needle access and responsive to pain</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Sino-atrial disorders
• All grades of AV block, Stokes-Adams syndrome, Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
• Acute porphyria
• Hypersensitivity to another local anesthetic of the amide type</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• After the second lidocaine dose is given, medication or fluids may be administered under pressure as required
• Can consider administering again in 45 minutes later at the lower of the two previous doses given if discomfort re-occurs
• If extravasation occurs insert a new IO needle
• Cimetidine or beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol) may interact and cause lidocaine toxicity</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Lidocaine 2% without epinephrine
drug_cards.notes: *Administer first dose over 2 minutes then allow lidocaine to dwell for 1 minute in IO space and flush with 5-10 mL 0.9% saline Followed by second dose of lidocaine over 1 minute

documents.title: Adult - Intravenous Line Maintenance Standard: pcp
documents.indications: <tab1>• Initiated by sending facility</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• To keep the vein open (TKVO)</tab1><tab2>
o The minimum flow rate to maintain IV patency for a patient ≥12 years of age is 30 mL/hr of any isotonic fluid (Normal saline or ringers lactate); or
</tab2><tab1>
• For fluid replacement
</tab1><tab2>o A maximum flow rate infused of up to 2 mL/kg/hr to a MAX of 200 mL/hr,
o Thiamine, multivitamin preparations,
o Drugs within his/her level of certification, or
o Potassium chloride (KCl) for patients ≥18 years of age, to a MAX of 10 mEq in a 250 mL or 40 mEq in a 1000 mL bag</tab2>

drug_cards.title: Maintain IV
dose_route: May transport a patient with a saline IV infusion containing thiamine, multivitamin preparations and KCl to a MAX of 40 mEq/Litre or D5W infusion as initiated by the sending hospital and maintain at the rate set by the sending facility up to a MAX of 200 mL/hr

documents.title: Adult - Blood Sampling and Lab Value Interpretation
documents.indications:
<tab1>• To establish baseline respiratory, cardiovascular, hematological status prior to or during transport
• To monitor changes and/or deterioration in clinical status</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
documents.clinical: <tab1>• These tests should only be completed if essential to patient management en route and will not cause unnecessary delays in transport</tab1>

dose_route: Perform venipuncture, venous blood sampling and utilize iSTAT if available Perform arterial blood sampling and utilize iSTAT if available Perform Umbilical Cord Blood Sampling and analyze using iSTAT if available All Abnormal lab values must be communicated to the TMP to discuss management strategies

documents.title: Adult - Maintaining and Accessing Central Venous Lines
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Actual or potential need for intravenous medication / fluid therapy
AND
• Central venous access is available</tab1>
You may access the following types of devices:
<tab1>• Hickman
• PICC (Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter)
• Central Venous Line</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Every lumen of a capped central line must be flushed prior to transport to ensure that they are patent and functional as per the Ornge Medical Procedure Manual
• Venous devices that are located subcutaneously, i.e. PortaCath or similar devices MAY NOT to be accessed
• Dialysis catheters will not be accessed without a TMP patch</tab1>

dose_route: Must be capped for transport Devices must not be accessed by the PCP

documents.title: Adult - Arterial Line Maintenance and Monitoring
documents.indications: <tab1>• Established arterial line</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• NS is the preferred solution for arterial lines with flush / pressure bag / transducer system unless sending facility has it heparinized in which case, one should continue as per sending
• Arterial lines are not to be capped or locked due to the risk of thrombosis. Instead, it must be removed if not transduced
• Arterial lines are calibrated (zeroed) with any changes in level of bed &/or position of head of bed to transducer, if waveform changes and with IV tubing changes
• Ensure all connections are tight , line is secured (ie arm board) and limb properly restrained as required
• Blood backing up the transducer tubing from the patient may indicate a leak, crack or loose connections</tab1>

dose_route: Perform blood sampling and utilize iSTAT if available
Monitor and transduce an established arterial line

documents.title: Adult - Pulmonary Artery Catheters Auxiliary Medical Directive
documents.indications: <tab1>• A CCP may provide the treatment prescribed in this auxiliary medical directive if certified and authorized</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• If the arterial line and PA catheter cannot be simultaneously monitored then the arterial line will be monitored and the PA line will be removed. Authorized CCPs may remove the PA catheters prior to transport if required. The catheter must be completely removed, not just pulled back into the right atrium or SVC. The introducer (cordis) should be left in-situ and a plug inserted so that a new PA line may be inserted at the receiving facility
• If the patient must be transported with a PA catheter in place, and no authorized CCP is available, the sending facility must send an appropriate escort with the responsibility for care and monitoring of the PA catheter under the sending facility staff</tab1>

documents.title: Adult - Stroke
documents.indications: <tab1>• Acute stroke</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Traumatic head injury
• Blood glucose < 4 mmol</tab1>
documents.clinical: <tab1>• Refer to Stroke Clinical Practice Guidelines for appropriate Blood Pressure targets</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Labetalol Hold if HR < 60 bpm MAX dose 300 mg/day
dose_route:
<center>10-20 mg slow IV push q 20 minutes prn
until desired MAP achieved</center>

drug_cards.title: Hypertonic Saline (3%)
dose_route:
<center>3 mL/kg IV/IO
MAX rate of 20 mL/min
Consider if MAP < 80 mmHg</center>

documents.title: Adult - Seizures
documents.indications: <tab1>• Active Seizure</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• If blood glucose level ≤ 4 mmol/L, proceed with protocol for “Hypoglycemic Emergencies”.</tab1>
documents.treatment: If, on assessment, a patient is determined to be having a seizure, management of airway, breathing and circulation remain the first priority: adequate oxygenation and ventilation must be ensured.
documents.clinical: <tab1>• 0.2 micron filter must be used when administering phenyTOIN</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Midazolam (Versed) for Seizures
dose_route: 5 mg IV/IO doses repeated every 5 minutes, until seizure termination or MAX dose of 0.2 mg/kg IV/IO in total OR 10 mg IM if no IV/IO access

drug_cards.title: Levetiracetam (Keppra)
dose_route:
<center>60 mg/kg/dose IV/IO MAX 4500 mg/dose
Infuse over 5 minutes</center>

drug_cards.title: phenyTOIN (Dilantin)
dose_route: 20 mg/kg add to 250 mL NS IV/IO Infusion should be no faster than 25 mg/min USE NORMAL SALINE ONLY phenyTOIN will precipitate in dextrose solutions

drug_cards.title: Propofol
dose_route:
<center>50 mg IV/IO q 5 minutes prn if MAP > 70
Prepare to intubate
Followed by infusion at 0-5 mg/kg/hr</center>

documents.title: Care of the Agitated or Combative Patient
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Hemodynamically stable patients, assessed to be experiencing ongoing agitation, psychotic features or impulsivity, requiring sedation for patient and crew safety concerns.
• In the event that a patient becomes agitated or combative, thereby endangering themselves or crew, ALL paramedics are expected to:
• Physically restrain the patient as MOHLTC Basic Life Support – Patient Care Standards
• Patients experiencing the effects of alcohol intoxication withdrawal should be treated with the corresponding medical directive
• Patient ≥ 12 years of age</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.treatment:
<tab1>• Assess and manage ABC’s, vitals and blood glucose.
• Assess the patient for medical causes of agitation (i.e. hypoxemia, hypoglycemia, etc.).
• Make all efforts to anticipate treatment requirements prior to initiating transport. In such cases, contact the TMP to discuss the treatment plan prior to administering these medications.
• When possible, utilize strategies to manage the environment, use behavioral de-escalation techniques and use calming interventions (see clinical notes) to de-escalate the patient so that they are not a harm risk to themselves/crew.
• For patients experiencing pain, utilize the analgesia medical directive.
• Refer to clinical notes for advice on the recognition of agitation</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Administer Benztropine as an adjunct following Haldol or Olanzapine to mitigate the extra-pyramidal effects associated with these medications (especially at the higher end of the dosing range).</tab1>
<tab1>• Notify the flight crew immediately if in an aircraft.</tab1>
<tab1>• Recognition of Agitation:</tab1>
<tab2>o Mild: subtle behaviours such as fidgeting, irritability, fixed stare</tab2>
<tab2>o Moderate: raising voice, yelling, pacing, head/banging, defensive stance</tab2>
<tab2>o Severe: combative, imminent risk to self or others</tab2>
<tab1>• Manage the environment</tab1>
<tab2>o Remove dangerous objects/equipment</tab2>
<tab2>o Decrease sources of stress/stimulation, including family/caregivers as required to reduce patient triggers</tab2>
<tab1>• Behavioural De-escalation Techniques</tab1>
<tab2>o Respect personal space</tab2>
<tab2>o Listen to patient and caregiver</tab2>
<tab2>o Keep neutral tone and body language</tab2>
<tab2>o Establish concise verbal contact</tab2>
<tab2>o Avoid provocative actions and words</tab2>
<tab2>o Identify wants and feelings</tab2>
<tab2>o Offer choices and optimism</tab2>
<tab2>o Reward cooperation</tab2>
<tab1>• Calming Interventions</tab1>
<tab2>o Listen to patient, validate distress</tab2>
<tab2>o Address needs (food/drink) where appropriate/possible</tab2>
<tab2>o Use distraction (i.e. safe activity, warm blanket etc.).</tab2>
<tab2>o Explain what to expect in the ED, next steps, updates</tab2>
<tab2>o Debrief patient and care team</tab2>

drug_cards.section: Identify the etiology for agitation: Unkown Etiology with mild-moderate agitation
dose_route: MAP > 70 0.05 mg/kg IV/IO OR 0.1 mg/kg IM q 5 minutes prn 0.2 MAX dose 0.2 mg/kg IV/IM/IO

drug_cards.notes: *Give high IV doses of Ketamine slow push (over > 1 minute) to reduce risk of apnea *If possible, administer using a 50 ml NS bag over 5-10 minutes • If primary psychiatric diagnosis, contact TMP for Haloperidol - see dosing below
NOTE: In Patients > 65 years of age, start with 2.5 mg
dose_route: 2.5 mg - 5.0 mg IV every 5-10 minutes IV To a Maximum of 30 mg OR 10 mg of Haloperidol IM Repeat, X 1 if required and patch with TMP
5mg - 10mg PO OR 5mg - 10mg IM MAX dose to be discussed with TMP

<center>1.0mg - 2.0mg IM PRN
Adjunct to reduce EPS from antipsychotic medications
MAX dose to be discussed with TMP</center>

drug_cards.notes: *Avoid benzodiazepine due to risk of disinhibition, unless effective in the past; avoid IM route if possible
dose_route: 5mg - 10mg PO OR 5mg - 10mg IM MAX dose to be discussed with TMP
5mg - 10mg PO OR 5mg - 10mg IM MAX dose to be discussed with TMP

drug_cards.notes: *Avoid benzodiazepine and anticholinergics, which could worsen delirium
dose_route: 2.5 mg - 5.0 mg IV every 5-10 minutes IV To a Maximum of 30 mg OR 10 mg of Haloperidol IM Repeat, X 1 if required and patch with TMP MAX dose to be discussed with TMP

drug_cards.section: Withdrawal or intoxication • Assess for multidrug ingestion • If indicated, refer to Care of Alcohol Intoxication Withdrawal Medical Directive for guidance
dose_route: MAP > 70 0.05 mg/kg IV/IO OR 0.3 mg/kg IM q 5 minutes prn 0.4 MAX dose 0.2 mg/kg IV/IM/IO

documents.title: Adult - Alcohol Intoxication Withdrawal
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Management of clinical concerns associated with alcohol withdrawal.</tab1>
<tab1>• Other conditions can mimic or coexist with alcohol withdrawal, including:</tab1>
<tab2>• Drug overdose</tab2>
<tab2>• Trauma (intracranial hemorrhage)</tab2>
<tab2>• Infection</tab2>
<tab2>• Metabolic derangements</tab2>
<tab2>• Hepatic failure</tab2>
<tab2>• Gastrointestinal bleeding</tab2>
<tab1>• Consider additional diagnostics and evaluation to rule out alternative diagnosis, especially if presentation includes altered mental status and/or fever.</tab1>
<tab1>• Use the</tab1>
<tab1>• Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment for Alcohol (CIWA-Ar) score to implement medication strategies to achieve light somnolence or to achieve minimal to moderate sedation</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable.</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• The Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment for Alcohol, revised (CIWA-Ar) scale has ten items, each evaluated independently then aggregated to yield a score correlating with severity of alcohol withdrawal.</tab1>
<tab1>• The CIWA-Ar provides an efficient (<5 mins) and objective means of assessing alcohol withdrawal that can then be utilized in treatment protocols</tab1>
<tab1>• CIWA-Ar cannot be used effectively in intubated/sedated patients. A sedation scale such as the Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) is more appropriate in this setting</tab1>
<tab1>• Consider Vitamin B1 (thiamine) for chronically malnourished alcoholics to prevent Wernicke’s</tab1>
<tab1>• Consider electrolyte replacement if indicated – especially magnesium and potassium if hypomagnesic/ hypokalemic or cardiac dysrhythmia or neuromuscular irritability</tab1>
<tab1>• Patients frequently under-report alcohol use and physicians often can overlook alcohol problems in patients (Kitchens JM 1994). It is estimated that 1 of every 5 patients admitted to a hospital abuses alcohol (Schuckit 2001)</tab1>
<tab1>• Unrecognized alcohol withdrawal can lead to potentially life-threatening consequences including seizures and delirium tremens</tab1>
<tab1>• There is no absolute relationship between alcohol use pattern and risk of physiologic dependence or withdrawal for a given individual. In general, any suspicion of daily alcohol use over several weeks or more, regardless of quantity, should raise concern for potential alcohol withdrawal</tab1>
<tab1>• Additional variables that may contribute to risk include age, medical comorbidities like hepatic dysfunction, concomitant medication use, and low seizure threshold1</tab1>

dose_route: Assess Using Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment for Alcohol (CIWA-Ar)
5-20 mg IV/PO q 15 minutes PRN To achieve a CIWA-Ar ≤ 20 MAX dose to be discussed with TMP

drug_cards.section: AND THEN (if using LORazepam in preceding step)
dose_route: 0.5-4 mg IV/SL/PO q 15 minutes PRN To achieve a CIWA-Ar ≤ 20 MAX dose to be discussed with TMP

drug_cards.section: For Subsequent medication dosing, adjust based on hourly CIWA-Ar scores: Subsequent CIWA-Ar score ≥ 20 - Severe Agitation
dose_route:
<center>10-20 mg IV/PO q 1 hour PRN
To achieve a CIWA-Ar ≤ 20</center>

<center>2-4 mg IV/SL/PO q 1 hour PRN
To achieve a CIWA-Ar ≤ 20</center>

<center>5-10 mg PO q 6 hours PRN
To control residual symptoms</center>

drug_cards.section: OR For hallucinations not controlled by adequate doses of benzodiazepines:
drug_cards.notes: NOTE: In Patients > 65 years of age, start with 2.5 mg
dose_route:
<center>2.5 mg - 5.0 mg IV every 5-10 minutes
To a Maximum of 30 mg
OR
10 mg IM</center>

<center>1-2 mg IM x 1
Adjunct to reduce EPS from antipsychotic medications</center>

<center>4 mg IV in 50-100 mL NS over ≥ 15 minutes q 8 hours PRN
OR
4 to 8 mg PO q 8 hours PRN</center>

documents.title: Adult - Traumatic Cardiac Arrest
documents.indications: <tab1>• Adult patient is vital signs absent (VSA) due to trauma</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable.</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• If this is inter-facility then a STAT patch to the TMP is indicated for further management decision making
• Routinely bind pelvis if MOI suggests potential for pelvic injury
• Perform bilateral needle thoracostomy in acute traumatic arrest
• If no obvious external signs of significant blunt trauma, consider medical cardiac arrest and treat according to ‘Adult Non-Traumatic Cardiac Arrest’ MDSO</tab1>
<tab2>o Signs of life include: any spontaneous movement; respiratory efforts; organized electrical activity on ECG; reactive pupils</tab2>

<tab1>• Recent evidence has suggested that hypertonic saline appears to be superior to mannitol in the reduction of the combined burden of intracranial hypertension and associated hypoperfusion in Severe TBI. Refer to CPG
• Trauma patients should be kept warm with temperature > 35 degrees
• TMP contact is required following the initiation of Norepinephrine to discuss ongoing management and make TMP aware of potential deterioration in patient condition</tab1>

dose_route:
<center>3 mL/kg IV/IO
MAX rate of 20 mL/min
</center>

documents.clinical: <tab1>• In neurogenic shock (if not also hypovolemic) there is sufficient alpha activity at low doses of levophed that significant reflex bradycardia may arise due to unopposed vasoconstriction and carotid body stimulation/vagal tone. In this situation, dopamine may be considered</tab1>

documents.title: Adult - Traumatic Hemorrhagic Shock
documents.indications: <tab1>• Hemorrhagic shock SBP < 90 mmHg with active, ongoing and significant bleeding</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Avoid hypothermia. Keep patient’s temperature above 35°C
• Permissive hypotension should be considered for patients suffering penetrating torso injury
• Target systolic blood pressure should be 90 mmHg. However, in all cases, perfusion of the brain (level of consciousness) must be maintained</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Consider RBC and TXA
dose_route: See Blood Product Administration Medical Directive and TXA Medical Directive

documents.title: Adult - Blood Product Administration
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Hemorrhagic shock MAP < 65 mmHg with active, ongoing and significant bleeding
• Hemoglobin < 70 grams/litre with evidence of circulatory compromise
• TMP judgement</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Contact the TMP to request Red Blood Cells (RBCs) at the scene. This would only be indicated in very rare individual circumstances i.e. uncontrolled hemorrhagic shock despite adequate crystalloid resuscitation, prolonged out-of-hospital time (i.e. prolonged extrication) and no significant delay to arrival to patient caused by waiting to retrieve the blood
• Ensure all available identifiers (i.e. name, blood type, patient number, etc) are checked to ensure correct blood product transfusion
• Once any of the above products are administered, the blood product form must be completed and submitted to the receiving institution, so that they are aware
• Informed consent for blood product administration must be obtained if Ornge initiates the blood product (please refer to the consent form in the Clinical Affairs P&P manual) except in life threatening circumstances
• Please note, if immediate RBCs are required for an unstable patient request Type O blood if available (O Negative for women of child bearing age)</tab1>

dose_route:
<center>1-2 PRBC to maintain
MAP > 65 mm Hg or Hgb > 70 as directed</center>
<center>2 U for every 2 U PRBC delivered</center>

<center>1-2 RBC to maintain
MAP > 65 mm Hg or Hgb > 70 as directed</center>
<center>2 U for every 2 U PRBC delivered</center>

• Consider a lower threshold to activate the MHP for geriatric patients (> 65 years)</tab1>

<center>Calcium – administer after 2nd unit of RBC and q 4 units after - monitor and replace as practical</center>
