documents.title: Adult - Tranexamic Acid (TXA) Administration
documents.indications: • Treatment of trauma-associated hemorrhage, management of massive bleeding, or prophylaxis of systemic or local hyperfibrinolysis • Tranexamic acid should be administered as soon as IV/IO access is achieved but within 3-hours from time of injury or within 3-hours from MHP activation in all other patients • HR > 100 OR • SBP < 100 mmHg
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Known hypersensitivity to TXA
• Greater than 3 hours from time of injury to drug administration (for traumatic injury)</tab1>
documents.clinical: <tab1>• If active bleeding persists, additional 1 gram bolus doses of TXA may be indicated. Discuss with TMP.</tab1>

documents.title: Adult - Push Dose EPINEPHrine (10 mcg/ml = 1: 100 000)
documents.indications: <tab1>• Temporary improvement of circulation in peri-arrest or shock states with severe hypotension and/or bradycardia</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Patients in cardiac arrest</tab1>
documents.clinical: • Epinephrine 10 mcg/ml may provide temporary stabilization while other therapies are added or adjusted/ titrated • Resuscitation involving push dose EPINEPHrine is expected to be performed in consultation with the TMP Preparation of Push Dose Epinephrine - 10 mcg/ml concentration Using a 10 mL syringe, draw 100 microgram (i.e. 1 mL of 1:10,000) EPINEPHrine and dilute in 9 mL of Normal Saline

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin) 10 mcg/ml - 1: 100 000
dose_route:
<center>5-20 mcg IV/IO q 2-5 minutes PRN
Target MAP >65</center>

documents.title: Adult - Hypovolemic Shock
documents.indications: <tab1>• Hypotensive as defined by a MAP < 65 mmHg as a result of hypovolemia</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Following consultation with the TMP, volume replacement therapy, can be continued by the ACP(f), CCP and PCCP/PCCN with the intent of keeping the patient’s MAP within a normotensive range (i.e. ≥ 65 mmHg). Severe hypovolemia from blood loss should prompt consideration for early use of blood products including both packed red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma in cases of massive transfusion (see Blood Product Administration Medical Directive)
• In setting of hemorrhage consider early blood component therapy (BCT) and limit crystalloid to 1L - use NS for BCT
• Avoid crystalloid in large doses in hemorrhagic shock particularly in trauma
• Crystalloids are indicated in hemorrhagic shock if delay for blood with hypotension and altered mentation
• Consider TXA if severe hemorrhagic shock</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Normal Saline or Ringers Lactate
dose_route:
<center>20 mL/kg IV/IO bolus
MAX 1 Litre
REPEAT bolus if patient continues to be symptomatically hypotensive
Target MAP > 65</center>

drug_cards.title: Consider RBCs and FFP
dose_route: See Blood Product Administration Medical Directive

documents.title: Adult - Septic Shock
documents.indications: <tab1>• Septic shock (MAP < 65)</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Consider 1 g CaCl in 100 mL NS/1 hour if ionized Ca < 1 or Ca < 2.0 (corrected if available)
• For patients that are profoundly hypotensive with MAP <50 or pre-arrest consider emergent TMP patch to discuss epinephrine 1: 100 000 and start Norepinephrine infusion at minimum 0.3 mcg/kg/min. Crystalloid bolus should be given concurrently with push dose pressors and/or Norepinephrine infusion initiation
• If Hydrocortisone not available consider Methylprednisolone 125 mg IV/IO
• Consider HCO3 if pH <7.1
• Target of 1h from patient contact at sending to receive appropriate antibiotics</tab1>

Target MAP > 65</center>

dose_route: When initiated appropriately by a sending facility: Maintain existing antimicrobial infusions Administer repeat antimicrobial doses within the prescribed time interval New/modified antimicrobial administration requires a TMP patch

documents.title: Adult - Extravasation of Vasopressors from Peripheral IV Infusion
documents.indications: <tab1>• Extravasation of norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine, DOBUTamine, vasopressin, or phenylephrine from peripheral IV site</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Extravasation of vasopressors may potentially cause necrosis of tissue around the IV site or possibly compartment syndrome. Whenever possible, a central line should be used. If peripheral IV access is the only route available, try to avoid the hand or wrist whenever possible. Any IV pressor site should be kept visible and examined q 15 minutes to assess for extravasation
• The phentolamine may cause systemic hypotension, but should be addressed if the secondary IV site is running the original pressor</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Phentolamine (within 12 hour of extravasation)
dose_route: <center>0.1 mg/kg to a max of 10 mg in 9 mL of NS (using a different syringe should be injected) half through the problematic IV catheter over 60 seconds and half as a Sub Q injection around the site using a 25G – 30G needle into any area where tissue discoloration or swelling is seen</center>

documents.contraindications:

• Prolonged QT interval or concomitant use of other drugs that may prolong the QT interval (specific to Ondansetron)</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• dimenhyDRINATE should be administered SLOW IV push to prevent vertigo, weakness and dizziness</tab1>
<tab1>• for nausea/vomiting related to motion sickness, dimenhyDRINATE is the most appropriate anti-nauseant</tab1>

OR

OR

drug_cards.notes: *Black box warnings due to risk of prolonged QT • All IV doses must be diluted in 50–100 mL of saline or other compatible fluid • All IV doses must be infused over no less than 15 minutes

documents.title: Adult - Invasive Temperature Monitoring
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Continuous monitoring of core body temperature for any intubated patient with a temperature outside normal range (36.5 to 37.5oC)
• Temperature monitoring during active rewarming measures
• Continuous monitoring may be ordered by the TMP at their discretion
• Required for targeted temperature management in ROSC</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Esophageal strictures
• Esophageal varices
• Esophageal perforation
• Congenital anomalies such as tracheal esophageal fistula
• Post-Operative tonsil and adenoidectomy patients
• Facial trauma
• Patients receiving Anticoagulants. Anticoagulants include but are not limited to: IV Heparin, Warfarin (Coumadin), Enoxaparin (Lovenox)</tab1>
documents.clinical: <tab1>• It is preferable to assess position of probe using a CXR but should not delay transport</tab1>

dose_route: Insert and monitor core temperature with esophageal or rectal temperature probe

documents.contraindications:

• Perineal or scrotal hematoma

• High riding prostate</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Urinary catheter removal can only be performed by the ACP(f)and CCP
• If during transport the catheter becomes obstructed contact the TMP</tab1>

documents.title: Adult - Continuous Bladder Irrigation
documents.indications: <tab1>• Maintenance of Continuous Bladder irrigation initiated by sending facilities</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Inability to safely secure equipment</tab1>

<tab1>• CBI should preferentially be discontinued for transport. If d/c is not appropriate, CBI may be maintained during transport.</tab1>
<tab1>• Documentation should include the following:</tab1>
<tab2>o Type of irrigation fluid</tab2>
<tab2>o Volume infused</tab2>
<tab2>o Amount and colour of drainage</tab2>
<tab2>o Presence/absence of clots</tab2>
<tab2>o Rate of irrigation (slow/moderate/fast)</tab2>
<tab2>o Drainage volume</tab2>
<tab3>• Net urine output is calculated by subtracting the total volume of irrigant infused from the total volume of drainage</tab3>

Initiated by sending facility & not appropriate for discontinuation during transport</center>

documents.indications: <tab1>• Fever - temperature >38oC</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Acetaminophen within the last 4 hours
• Ibuprofen:</tab1><tab2>
• NSAID or Ibuprofen use within previous 6 hours
• Patient on anticoagulation therapy
• Current active bleeding
• Hx of peptic ulcer disease or GI bleed
• Pregnant
• If asthmatic, no prior use of ASA or other NSAIDs
• CVA or TBI in the previous 24 hours
• Known renal impairment
• Active vomiting
• Unable to tolerate oral medication</tab2>
documents.clinical: <tab1>• Total acetaminophen dose in 24 hours is not to exceed the lesser of 75 mg/kg or 4 grams</tab1>

AND

documents.title: Adult - Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)
documents.indications: • Hyperglycemia (blood glucose > 11 mmol/L) in a new or known diabetic AND • pH <7.30, serum bicarbonate <15 mmol/L and anion gap > 12 mmol/L AND (if available) • Confirmed ketosis (positive ketones in blood or urine) Monitoring: • Cardiorespiratory monitor and O2 saturation monitor • Monitoring of vital signs (HR, RR, BP) and neurovitals, q 10-15 minutes • Accurate intake and output q 1 hour • Bedside glucose q 1 hour
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• A normal or mildly elevated blood glucose level does not rule out diabetic ketoacidosis in certain conditions, such as pregnancy or with SGLT2 inhibitor use.</tab1>
<tab1>• Diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state are medical emergencies that require treatment and monitoring for multiple metabolic abnormalities and vigilance for complications.</tab1>
<tab1>• Diabetic ketoacidosis requires intravenous insulin administration (0.1 units/kg/h) for resolution. Bicarbonate therapy may be considered only for extreme acidosis (pH ≤7.0).</tab1>
<tab1>• Diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state should be suspected in people who have diabetes and are ill. If either diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state is diagnosed, precipitating factors must be sought and treated.</tab1>
<tab1>• Although the diagnosis and treatment of DKA in adult and in children share general principles, there are significant differences in their application, largely related to the increased risk of life-threatening cerebral edema with DKA in children and adolescents.</tab1>
<tab1>• Refer to DKA flow chart</tab1>

drug_cards.title: 3% Mucomyst (Acetylcysteine)* Dosage Guide and Preparation for IV Administration (reference CPS)
drug_cards.notes: *Please refer to MucomystTM (acetylcysteine) Drug Monographs profile

documents.clinical: • In severe acetaminophen overdose, discuss the role of Fomepizole (Antizol) with the TMP to determine if indicated • Calculate Acetylcysteine dose using total body weight up to a maximum of 100 kg • *If local reaction or rash occurs: Stop the infusion temporarily, treat with antihistamines, ventolin prn, then restart infusion at ½ the rate • Mandatory Patch required to initiate an acetylcysteine infusion • The ACP(f) and CCP may maintain the administration of a MucomystTM (acetylcysteine) infusion as per the above table for an Acetaminophen overdose in the following circumstances: ◦ The infusion was initiated by the sending facility ◦ Ingested or suspected ingestion of Acetaminophen dose is greater or equal to: • 10 g TOTAL OR • 200 mg/kg ideal body weight ◦ The rate of infusion is in accordance with the accompanying dosage table and preparation guide ◦ The rate of infusion cannot be altered by the Paramedic unless ordered by the Transport Medicine Physician Guidelines to Prepare a 3% Intravenous N-Acetylcysteine Bag As part of the Poison Centre’s treatment recommendations for the acetaminophen-poisoned patient, a 3 % nacetylcysteine solution will need to be prepared. The following are instructions on how to prepare this solution in D5W. Patient is > 40 kg • Remove 150 ml from a 1000 ml bag of D5W • Add 150 ml of 20% IV N-Acetylcysteine to the remaining 850 ml in the D5W bag ◦ 150 ml X 200 mg/ml = 30 000 mg of N-Acetylcysteine ◦ 30 000 mg in 1000 ml yields a final solution with 30 mg/ml or 3% NOTES: 1. 20% IV N-Acetylcysteine is equivalent to 200 mg/ml 2. The 3% solution is slightly hyperosmolar but still within the safety margin for administration via a peripheral vein 3. It is recognized that any particular bag of IV fluid could have excessive fluid more than advertised. It is of little consequence when making this 3% solution. Assume a finished volume as advertised on the bag Mixing is important to ensure uniform distribution of N-Acetylcysteine in infusion solution

documents.title: Obstetrics - Pre-eclampsia / Eclampsia
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Symptoms of pre-eclampsia/eclampsia and pregnant or post—partum within 28 days
• Pre-eclampsia with severe features is defined as including Proteinuria, Platelets <100,000, a doubling of the serum creatinine, LFT 2x normal, pulmonary edema, or cerebral or visual symptoms</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.treatment: If, on assessment, a patient is determined to be having a seizure, management of airway, breathing and circulation remain the first priority: adequate oxygenation and ventilation must be ensured.
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Eclamptic seizures are almost always self-limiting and seldom last longer than three to four minutes (usual duration 60 to 75 seconds). Magnesium loading dose is used to prevent recurrent seizures
• The magnesium dosage regimen should not cause toxicity in normal renal function
• In event of magnesium toxicity (i.e. respiratory depression/paralysis, severe hypotension) give calcium chloride
• Magnesium sulphate is recommended as prophylaxis against eclampsia in women with severe preeclampsia
• Routine monitoring of serum magnesium levels is not recommended
• Phenytoin and benzodiazepines should not be used for eclampsia prophylaxis or treatment, unless there is a contraindication to magnesium sulphate or it is ineffective</tab1>

documents.title: Transport Medicine Physician (TMP) - Escalation Patch
documents.indications: <tab1>Patient clinical status may change from the time of booking of transport to initial patient contact with transport crews. This medical directive is to provide guidance for Ornge Primary Care Paramedics (PCP) as to when to patch with the Ornge TMP for further clinical guidance and advice.</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• N/A</tab1>
documents.clinical: 1. AGE AND VITAL SIGNS The general age cut off between adults and pediatrics is 18 years. There is a wide range of “normal” for vital signs in adults and especially pediatrics. PCP should consider patch to TMP when vital signs are outside of the following “normal” ranges: ADULTS Hypotension-SBP<90 mmHg Bradycardia-<50 BPM Tachycardia->100 BPM Tachypnea-RR ≥28 breath/min Oxygen Saturation-<90% on room air or patient’s usual supplemental oxygen setting GCS:<15-(unless at their baseline level. Any change from baseline GCS should prompt a TMP patch. PEDIATRICS AGE Respiratory Rate Heart Rate 0-3 months 30-60 90-180 3-6 months 30-60 80-160 6-12 months 25-45 80-140 1-3 yr 20-30 75-130 6 yr 16-24 70-110 10 yr 14-20 60-90 Systolic Blood Pressure (for children 1-10 yrs) = 70 + (2 x age in years) Weight (kg) = (age x 2) + 10 2. HYPOGLYCEMIA Age ≥2 years: glucometry <4.0 mmol/L Age <2 years: glucometry <3.0 mmol/L 3. CHANGES TO CLINICAL STATUS Every transport request is reviewed by a TMP. In some cases, these transports are booked the day before. During this time, the clinical condition of patients may change and as such no longer be appropriate for primary paramedic level of care. Please make every effort to ensure the current clinical status of the patient mirrors that provided in the pre-transport booking information. When there is a change in a clinical status that has the potential to cause complications or puts that patient at higher risk for patient decompensation, please inform the TMP. 4. ARRHYTHMIAS Patch to the TMP when the patient has a heart rhythm that is new, not confirmed prior and/or the paramedic is concerned that the cardiac rhythm may cause complications during the transport. 5. PROLONGED TARMAC DELAYS In situations of prolonged tarmac delays for land transport into the receiving facility, changes to the clinical status of patients can be subtle. Regardless of the presence of additional escorts, diligence and careful monitoring of patients is required for changes to hydration, temperature, level of consciousness, glucose levels and other vital signs. Patch to the TMP in any change to clinical status during prolonged tarmac delays. The OCC will inform the TMP for any tarmac delay exceeding 180min along with the Provincial Duty Officer and the OCC Manager. 6. TARMAC DELAYS DURING EXTREMES OF TEMPERATURE Given aircraft are unable to maintain environmental controls while stationary on the ground, crews should identify to OCC when they are on delay with a patient and ambient temperatures at the airport are above 25° Celsius or below – 10° Celsius for review for ‘Delays During Extreme Temperatures’.

documents.title: Paediatric - Supraglottic Airway
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Weight >2 kg
• Need for ventilatory assistance OR airway control AND
• Other airway management is inadequate OR ineffective OR unsuccessful</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Intact gag reflex
• Caustic ingestion
• Active vomiting</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Supraglottic Airway
dose_route:
Insert Airway
MAX 2 attempts
Following two (2) failed attempts at supraglottic airway insertion, recommended 2 person BVM with oral/nasal pharyngeal airway management

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Supraglottic airway should be the initial airway strategy in out of hospital cardiac arrest unless endotracheal intubation is deemed more appropriate by the paramedic
• Endotracheal intubation is usually preferred for secure airway management in the non cardiac arrest patient. In this setting, SGA is considered a rescue device if BLS airway/ventilation and other advanced airway maneuvers have been unsuccessful
• Confirm placement with ETCO2</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Pre-Intubation and Intubation Medications
documents.indications:
<tab1>• All Intubation attempts in paediatric patients older than newborn
• Newborn infants should be intubated preferably using Atropine, Fentanyl and Succinylcholine</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>

drug_cards.section: For Sedation Choose only one sedative agent +/- analgesic

Use 0.5 mg/kg in patient exhibiting signs of shock</center>

*Apnea and hypotension may occur with rapid induction
*Avoid use in hypovolemia or patients with poor cardiovascular reserve
*Should be avoided in patients with head injury who are hemodynamically unstable/periarrest
Cuffed ETT (age in years/4) + 3.5
ETT depth >1 year: 3 x ETT size

drug_cards.section: For RSI For Paralysis ROCURONIUM IS THE PREFERRED PARALYTIC IN THE MAJORITY OF PATIENTS > NEWBORN
drug_cards.title: RSI Dosages:
dose_route: Administer atropine prior to the administration of Succinylcholine Caution in patients if HR > 180

drug_cards.notes: *Contraindications to Succinylcholine: • Should not be used if family history of Malignant hyperthermia • Hyperkalemia (known or concern) • Myopathies/Muscular dystrophies • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, Multiple Sclerosis • Guillain-Barre Syndrome, botulism • Burns ≥ 2nd degree over 10% BSA >5 days until healed • Spinal cord injury >5 days until 6 months post injury *Atropine (used in children < 1 year old) • Anticholinergic agent • Used to prevent bradycardia which can occur with the use of Succinylcholine or vagal stimulation • Onser of action: 1-2 minutes • Duration: 2 hours • Atropine should not be used in patients with a history of dysrhythmias or sustained tachycardia (>200 beats per minute in the previous 24 hours) • If Atropine is not being used for premedication in children <1 year, it should be readily available to treat any bradycardia that may occur duing the intubation procedure

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Rocuronium may be used if Succinylcholine is contraindicated
• Propofol may be preferred in clinical circumstances such as closed head injury in the absence of hemodynamic instability
</tab1>

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Multiple doses of Ipratropium (three) added to Salbutamol administration and together with oral corticosteroid administration in the first 60 minutes of treatment yield greater improvement in children with severe respiratory distress
• Add Normal Saline to Atrovent and Salbutamol dose to make a final volume of 3 mL. When administering as a nebulized treatment Atrovent should not be given alone. Nebulized Atrovent is given with Salbutamol dose.
• Side effects of Magnesium Sulfate include hypotension, muscle fatigue and acute pulmonary edema; monitor BP and respiratory status closely
• Consider IV Salbutamol in severe asthma exacerbations; monitor heart rate and rhythm, glucose (hyperglycemia) and electrolytes (hypokalemia)
• Utilize the aerogen nebulizer for inline nebulization treatments where appropriate</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Croup – Suspected Cases
documents.indications:
<tab1>• A current history of an upper respiratory infection with a “barking” cough
AND
• Inspiratory stridor at rest, or marked accessory muscle use, or an altered level of consciousness, or cyanosis</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin) Nebulized (1 mg/ml 1:1000 solution)
dose_route:
<center>0.5 mg/dose
Dilute dose to 3mL in Normal Saline</center>

Dilute dose to 3 mL in Normal Saline</center>

dose_route:
<center>0.5 mg/kg/dose PO, IM, IV*
MAX 12 mg</center>

<center>Administer orally if patient able to swallow
or
If unable to tolerate oral administration due to respiratory distress and no IV access, administer IM</center>
drug_cards.notes: *No IV administration for PCP

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Most common causes of upper airway obstruction in young children 
• Typical age of presentation is between 6 months and 5 years with a peak at 2 years of age
• Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for all children who present to the ED with croup symptoms
• Nebulized epinephrine is recommended for moderate to severe croup
• Repeat the administration of EPINEPHrine nebulized using the same dose if no improvement is observed within ten minutes following the first treatment
• Following initial treatment may administer by nebulizer prn to a max q 1h
• For patients with HR > 200/min prior to EPINEPHrine nebulization, continue to monitor heart rate and rhythm; exclude arrhythmias and evaluate need for acute fluid resuscitation
• Children who present with croup at < 6 months of age or whose symptoms are recurrent, prolonged or unusually severe require further assessment to rule out congenital or acquired airway narrowing
• Prolonged duration of croup symptoms associated with fever may be seen with secondary infection
• Toxic appearance, drooling and dysphagia are important red flags suggestive of more serious conditions (bacterial tracheitis, epiglottis and retropharyngeal abscess)
• Consider Aspiration or ingestion of a foreign body with presentation of croupy cough, choking episode, wheezing, hoarseness, biphasic stridor, dyspnea and decreased air entry
• Consider acute allergic reactions (anaphylaxis) with rapid onset of dysphagia, wheezing, stridor and cutaneous allergic signs such as urticarial rash</tab1>
Epineprhine Metered Dose Inhaler
< 5 kg: 1-2 puffs (0.125-0.25 mg)/dose
> 5 kg: 4-8 puffs (0.5-1 mg)/ dose
Given via spacer Q 4h prn (may titrate to effect up to q 1h)

documents.title: Paediatric - Thoracostomy - Needle
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Severe respiratory distress in the setting of chest trauma with hemodynamic compromise
OR
• Traumatic VSA
OR
• Severe hemodynamic compromise with positive pressure ventilation particularly with altitude in trauma or asthma
OR
• Either chest trauma or severe asthma and hemodynamic instability and one of the following:</tab1>
<tab2>o Decreased/absent breath sounds
o Altered LOC
o Cyanosis
o JVD (not seen in young children)
o Hyper resonance on affected side
o Tracheal shift (late sign)</tab2>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

dose_route: <center>Consider differential diagnosis and decompress if high probability of tension pneumothorax</center>

documents.clinical:
<tab1>•Quick Tip Calculations:
Chest tube: 4 x ETT size for age
• The patient must be seen as soon as possible at an appropriate facility for the insertion of chest tube(s)
• Consider differential diagnosis:
</tab1><tab2>o Mainstem intubation
o Pleural effusion
o Hemothorax
o Consolidated pneumonia
o Autopeep
o Dynamic hyperinflation</tab2>
<tab1>• Needle Thoracentesis
   Needle Sizes:
  Paediatric: 14‐16g 2‐inch needle
  Term neonate, infant, small child 20‐22g 1.0‐1.8 inch </tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Maintenance of Chest Tubes
documents.indications: <tab1>• Initiated by sending facility</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Maintain chest drainage systems during the call to keep the drainage system clear
dose_route: <center>If the patient’s chest tube was maintained by suction at the sending facility, the Paramedic may maintain suction to no greater than -20 cm H2O</center>

<center>If the patient’s chest tube was maintained by gravity drainage, the Paramedic should maintain gravity drainage to underwater seal, provided there is no evidence of deterioration due to reaccumulating air or fluid</center>

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• A Heimlich flutter valve is mandatory for transport if no drainage system has been implemented
• With suction on, continuous bubbling in the seal, may indicate the presence of a disconnect</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Mechanical Ventilation
documents.indications: <tab1>• The need to initiate or maintain mechanical ventilation</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• None</tab1>

dose_route: Perform leak test on ventilator circuit. Obtain baseline vital signs, including ETCO2. Confirm ETT placement (direct visualization if required, auscultation, and ETCO2) and ETT depth: Oral ETT depth(cm) • 1 month: 9-10 cm • 6 months: 10-12 cm • 1 year: 12-14 • 2 to 12 years: ETT size x 3 Check cuff pressure < 20 cm H2O after tube placement, and again in flight. Review indications for mechanical ventilation: • Respiratory failure (apnea/respiratory arrest, inadequate ventilation, inadequate oxygenation) • Cardiac insufficiency/shock • Neurologic dysfunction – cerebral hypoventilation/frequent apneas, GCS < 8, and inability to protect airway Review most recent chest xray or radiology report to confirm ETT position/depth and lung pathology. Review most recent blood gas post intubation if available. If blood gas is abnormal or no blood gas obtained, efforts should be made to obtain a blood gas once the patient is transitioned to an Ornge ventilator, and continuousEtCO2 monitoring is in place Document ETT size and depth (distance at the lips). Keep bag-valve mask, with peep valve and pressure manometer available for the duration of transport. Paediatric ETTs should be secured according to Ornge Policy & Procedures prior to transport. Ensure NG/ or OG tubes inserted.

Select mode of ventilation for patient (PSV if awake & spontaneously breathing or AC/SIMV if unable to breathe, heavily sedated or high ventilator settings required). SIMV PC + PS/AC to achieve • Target Vt 6-8 mL/kg. SIMV VC + PS/AC to achieve • Target Vt 6-8 mL/kg. PS general starting point 10 cm H2O • Range 5-20 cm H2O to achieve • Target Vt 6-8 ml/kg. Frequency (breaths per minute): • 1 month - 1 year 20-30 • 1 - 6 years 15-25 • > 6 years 15-20 PEEP (cm H2O): • Minimum PEEP of 5 for all patients. • Pulmonary Disease 5-15 • Abdominal Distention 5-15 (Ascites, bowel obstruction) Inspiratory time: • 1 month–1 year 0.50-0.70 • 1-6 years 0.60-0.90 • > 6 years 0.70-1.0 May use longer I-time to improve mean airway pressure and subsequently oxygenation. In obstructive airway disease, to increase Te, reduce RR to achieve I:E ratio 1:4 or 1:5. Reduced Ti is not recommended due to the risk of reduced Vt, requiring increased PIP and potential for barotrauma. Match FiO2 requirements from sending facility or target SpO2 >92% Adjust sensitivity to trigger with respiratory effort (normally 3). PIP < 30 cmH20 Plateau pressure < 30 cmH20 If already well ventilated, consider starting with referral ventilator settings. i.e. Pulmonary disease, ETT leaks i.e. Head trauma (no ETT leak) Target ETCO2 35-45 (or target ETCO2 as ordered by Paediatric TMP based on clinical diagnosis).
Alarm Guidelines
Set high pressure 5-10 cmH20 above the PIP. Set low pressure alarm 5-10 cmH20 below PIP. Set minute ventilation alarm at 75% of actual VE. If concerns re: abdominal distension due to ascites or bowel obstruction, ensure NGT/OGT is inserted and is the largest size appropriate for patient age

Document and monitor the following ventilator parameters:
<tab1>• Mode: AC, SIMV or PSV
• Pressure or Volume control
• Sensitivity
• Frequency
• Tidal volume
• Minute ventilation
• PIP
• PEEP
• Pressure support
• Mean airway pressure
• Inspiratory time
• I:E ratio
• FiO2

Monitor EtCO2 and capnographic waveforms throughout transport.
Monitor ventilator synchrony, work of breathing, chest rise and fall.
Monitor mean arterial pressure changes related to potential ventilator changes during transport.
Consider checking plateau pressure or auto PEEP if concerned about lung compliance or air trapping.

Recommended cuff pressure is just enough to seal the trachea.
Cuff pressure should be carefully adjusted to obtain a leak free seal at a pressure < 20 cm H2O.
Recheck cuff pressure in flight.

Prevent or treat autoPEEP Start PEEP at 5 cm H20 Use low frequency 8-12 breaths/min to a maximum of 16 breaths/min. Titrate frequency to maximize I:E ratio 1:4 to 1:5 allowing for long expiratory time. Adjust inspiratory time 0.75-1.0 based on age/weight. Use low tidal volume 4-6 mL/kg. Keep plateau pressure < 30 cmH20. Titrate ventilator parameters to achieve SpO2 >92%.

Intrinsic or autoPEEP can lead to worsening hypoxia, hypercapnia and hypotension. Severe airway obstruction may not allow complete expiration prior to the next delivered breath.nMonitor capnographic waveform for sloped expiratory rise indicating airflow obstruction. Difficult to ventilate/oxygenate: Optimize sedation; Consider muscle relaxing the patient Permissive Hypercapnia; Discuss with TMP regarding use of PEEP

Start PEEP at 5 cm H2O and titrate up as needed if FiO2 > 60%.
Use low frequency half of normal rate for patient age.
Set proper I-time for age/weight.
I:E ratio 1:3 to 1:4.
Tidal volumes 6-8 mL/kg.
Keep plateau pressure < 30 cmH2O.
Titrate Ventilator parameters to achieve SpO2 >92%.

Permissive hypercapnia if pH >7.25.
Assess adequacy of expiratory phase.
Aim to avoid or minimize hyperinflation.
Optimize sedation

Tidal volumes 6-8 mL/kg. Adjust Vt based on plateau pressures.
Start PEEP at 8 cm H2O; if FiO2 > 0.60 FiO2, titrate incremental increases in PEEP from 8 to 12 cm H2O to achieve SpO2 > 0.92. If no clinical improvements observed with increasing PEEP (increasing SpO2), STOP increasing PEEP. In severe paediatric ARDS, with no observed clinical improvements & continued SpO2 < 0.92, despite interventions, discuss further vent strategies, permissive hypoxia and hypercapnia parameters with paeds TMP
Keep plateau pressure < 30 cmH20.
FiO2 to maintain SpO2 > 90.
Inflamed lungs with decreased compliance and increased dead space are prone to atelectasis, barotrauma and volu-trauma.
Permissive hypercapnia (if pH > 7.25)
Increased I:E ratio can improve oxygenation by increasing mean airway pressure and helping to maintain PEEP. Aim for pH > 7.25 on blood gas
Avoid pulmonary de-recruitment (disconnections); may require manual recruitments using increased pressure for 30 to 40 seconds to recover.
Optimize sedation.
Consider muscle relaxing patient.

Neonatal Modes: (S)CMV (mode similar to PC AC/ Volume Guarantee (VG)) All breaths are mechanical breaths (initiated by ventilator) or assisted (initiated by patient) breaths All breaths are volume guaranteed Peak inspiratory pressure varies based on resistance of the airways and compliance of the lungs; tidal volume remains constant PCV+ (mode similar to PCAC) Set pressure control (PC) PIP remains the same, Vt varies based on resistance and compliance of patient Initial Settings: RR 30-40 breath per minute (adjust based on patient needs) PIP limit 25 cm H20 PEEP 5 cm H20 (adjust PEEP based on clinical response: FiO2 requirements, work of breathing, CXR findings) Vt 4-6 ml/kg Ti 0.3-0.4 sec (s)CMV is the preferred mode in Neonatal Ventilation If large ETT leak complicating ability to ventilate, consider using PCV+ mode Target blood gases: pH > 7.25 pCO2 45-55 mmHg Target SpO2 90-95% If increased ventilator support is needed and the infant is breathing above the ventilator rate, increasing the pressure or volume setting will be more effective than just increasing the ventilator rate. (if RR >80* consider increasing Vt and/or PEEP) Hypercapnia (persistent median PCO2 >60 mmHg) is a risk factor for acute brain injury in extremely low birth weight (ELBW) infants that may impair cerebral autoregulation and cause vasodilatation Hypocapnia(persistent median PCO2 < 32 mm Hg) are also associated with acute brain injury Important to recruit atelectatic lung by inflation and optimize lung volume: Target low tidal volumes (Vt) and increased PEEP Target blood gases: pH 7.25 – 7.35 pCO2 45 – 55 mm Hg pO2 50 – 60 mm Hg Avoid extreme fluctuations in pCO2 (especially during the first 72 hours of life due to an increased risk of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) Target pO2 50 – 60 mm Hg Notify TMP if HCO3 < 16 mmol/L or Base deficit > 8 mmol/L *If using a Volume Mode and any of the following clinical findings are present: -RR > 80 -VT > 6 ml/kg -PIP > 22-25 cmH2O -FiO2 > .40 -Inability to oxygenate or control CO2 Consider switching to PC AC mode

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• When mechanical ventilation is initiated, all settings and patient’s response to treatment must be documented on the Call Report
• The patient’s end tidal CO2, O2 saturation, and PIPs must be continuously monitored and recorded</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NPPV)
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Conscious patient
• Obstuctive airway disease; e.g. asthma
• Cardiac failure
• Chronic lung disease
• Acute/Chronic respiratory failure
• Neuromuscular disease
• Pneumonia</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Decreased level of consciousness
• Inability to protect airway
• Recent gastric or esophageal surgery
• Immediate need for endotracheal intubation
• Pneumothorax</tab1>

drug_cards.title: CPAP/BiPAP
dose_route:
Initiating CPAP and escalating NIV support to BiPAP is based on clinical assessment and should be considered if no improvement in WOB SpO2 of FiO2 requirements Initial Setting
Mild to moderate work of breathing: iPAP 6-8 cm H2O; increase to 10 cm H2O Moderate work of breathing: iPAP 10 cm H2O; increase to 15-18 cm H2O*
PEEP
If FiO2 is < 0. 40 start ePAP 5-6 cm H2O If FiO2 is > 0.40 to 0.80 start ePAP 8-10 cm H2O If FiO2 is > 0.80 start ePAP 10 cm H2O and increase to 12 cm H2O as tolerated
Invasive ventilation should be considered at these levels of O2 & support requirements

drug_cards.title: Neonatal Respiratory Support (NIV Modes): Hamilton T1
dose_route: nCPAP No set respiratory rate Spontaneous breathing mode PEEP 5-8 cmH2O nCPAP PC (Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation) NPPV Consider if nCPAP mode is failing despite maximum PEEP 10 cmH2O & FiO2 > 0.50 or infant has frequent episodes of bradycardia, desaturations and/or apnoea, high pCO2 and/or pH ≤7.25 Respiratory rate is operator set on ventilator or patient determined if > than ventilator set RR RR 20-40 (set ventilator rate) PC 8-15 cmH2O above PEEP (maximum PIP 25 cmH2O) PEEP 5-10 cmH2O (maximum PEEP 10 cm H2O) Ti 0.5-1.0 sec All infants receiving nCPAP/nCPAP PC should have an OGT placed Adjust FiO2 and PEEP to maintain SpO2 90-95% Target blood gases: pH 7.25 – 7.35 pCO2 45 – 55 mm Hg pO2 50 – 70 mm Hg If requiring increasing FiO2 (> 0.30) and/or increasing PEEP > 8 cmH2O, the Paediatric TMP should be contacted to review clinical status and discuss escalating respiratory support Contraindications to nCPAP PC include: • Ventilatory or significant oxygenation failure • Haemodynamic instability (Relative contraindication: May be reviewed with TMP) • Impending arrest • Tension Pneumothorax or enlarging existing pneumothorax Higher Ti (0.5-1.0 sec) are required in NPPV mode to allow time to conduct air flow to the alveoli/nOGTs should be vented (open to straight drainage) during transport

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Titrate iPAP based on disease process requiring NPPV e.g Asthma verses congestive heart failure (CHF) verses respiratory distress from other causes
• Start with a ePAP 5 cmH2O in asthmatic patients regardless of FiO2 needs due to air trapping and begin iPAP 8-10 cm H2O, titrating iPAP as tolerated
• Ensure mask fits securely to ensure adequate seal
• NGT/OGT to ensure gastric decompression during NPPV as tolerated by patient
• Monitor for for leaks and mask pressure around eyes and refit as required</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - High Flow Nasal Cannula Therapy (HFNC)
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Any patients who would benefit from heated humidity (e.g. bronchiolitis, pneumonia, patients with tenacious secretions, tracheostomy)
• Hypoxemia, as evidenced by suboptimal oxygen saturations below acceptable patient specific ranges, despite maximum recommended flow rates while receiving traditional O2 therapy (nasal cannula, face mask or hood)
• To alleviate mild to moderate work of breathing as evidenced by the following signs & symptoms:</tab1>
<tab2>o Tachypnea, nasal flaring, in-drawing, retractions and accessory muscle use
o Agitation, confusion or anxiety
o Tachycardia and/or heart rate variability</tab2>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Acute deterioration in level of consciousness
• When positive pressure ventilation is required (poor compliance, decreased functional residual capacity).
• NHFC therapy should not be used as an alternative to positive pressure ventilation or NPPV.
• Moderate to severe respiratory distress and/or impending cardio-respiratory failure with high partial arterial pressure of carbon dioxide
• Airway obstruction (e.g. Obstructive Sleep Apnea)
• Air leak (pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum) is a potential cause for concern and should be monitored closely
• Recent post-operative esophageal surgery or suspected bowel obstruction – mechanical or functional
• Suspected or confirmed base of skull fracture
• Epistaxis</tab1>
<title>Complications:</title>
<tab1>• Unmeasured PEEP may result in lung hyperinflation, pneumothorax (rare)
• Complications of HFNC include abdominal distension, aspiration, barotrauma, and pneumothorax (rare)</tab1>

dose_route: <center>Initiate treatment at 1.5-2 L/kg/min to achieve SpO2 >92%. Contact TMP if an increase in flow is indicated and/or FiO2 requirements exceed 0.60</center>

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Evaluate HR, RR and WOB on HFNC settings; if patient is receiving < 2L/kg/min and patient is requiring oxygen, consider escalating HFNC setting to 2L/kg/min
• Titrate FiO2 based on upon SpO2 target range
• If patient on HFNC settings of 2L/Kg/min and FiO2 requirement > 0.60, with no improvement in patient's condition, the Paediatric TMP should be contacted for discussion re: escalation of care
• In patients where HFNC settings are >2L/Kg/min, increased work of breathing may result from higher high flow rates. Patient may present as anxious due to difficulty exhaling, long expiratory times and forced expiration
• In infants especially, inserting and venting an orogastric tube, may be helpful in alleviating/ decreasing abdominal distension and may reduce the risk of aspiration</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric Analgesia: Non-Intubated Patients
documents.indications:
<tab1>• The provision of analgesia for non-intubated patients experiencing pain.
• Assess and document pain on all patients using a 10-point scale (0 = no pain, 10 = maximum pain).
• Document at least two pain scores on all patients and document a score before and after analgesia is provided to the patient.</tab1>
documents.contraindications: • Allergy or sensitivity to the medication • Acetaminophen • Acetaminophen use within the last 4 hours • History of liver disease • Ketorolac/Ibuprofen (NSAIDs) • NSAID in the past 6 hours • Impaired renal function • Active bleeding; do not use in Tonsillectomy patients

drug_cards.title: Acetaminophen (Tylenol)
dose_route:
<center>500-650 mg every 4 hours PO
Max single dose 650 mg</center>

drug_cards.title: Acetaminophen (Tylenol)
dose_route:
<center>15 mg/kg every 4 hours PO or PR
Max 1 gram
(Suspension or Suppository)</center>

drug_cards.title: Ketorolac
dose_route:
<center>0.5 mg /kg IV/IM q 6-8 h prn
Max 15 mg</center>

drug_cards.title: 24% Sucrose
dose_route:
<center>0.1 ml PO
2 minutes prior to painful procedure</center>
drug_cards.notes: • Dose may be repeated at 5 minute intervals for prolonged procedures • Contraindicated in short-bowel syndrome, carbohydrate intolerance, unconscious or heavily sedated patients with absent gag reflex; avoid use in patients with gastrointestinal tract abnormalities (e.g. esophageal atresia or tracheal esophageal fistula), in patients at risk for aspiration. Sucrose should not be used for patients requiring ongoing analgesia

drug_cards.section: Moderate to Severe Pain – Acetaminophen + NSAID AND one of FentaNYL OR Morphine OR Ketamine
drug_cards.title: FentaNYL (Sublimaze)
dose_route:
<center>0.5 -2 microgram/kg/dose IV q 10 min1 slowly over 2-3 minutes IV
(Max 40 mcg/dose)
OR
Intranasal 1.5 mcg/kg/dose q 5-10 min
Maximum volume 0.5 mL/nostril in infants or 1 mL/nostril in children
(Larger volumes should be divided between both nares)
Max 3 doses prior to TMP Patch
Note: Give 0.1 mL overfill to accommodate mucosal atomization device (MAD) dead-space volume</center>

drug_cards.title: Morphine
dose_route:
<center>0.05-0.1 mg/kg/dose IV q 15 min PRN
Max 5 mg/dose)
Max 3 doses prior to TMP Patch</center>

drug_cards.title: Ketamine Ketamine is NOT a first line agent for analgesia in normotensive patients but can be considered early for multiple trauma patients or those with concerning hemodynamic status
dose_route:
<center>0.5-1.5mg/kg IV/IO slowly over 1-2 minutes
May repeat 0.5 mg/kg in 10 minutes
OR
0.75 mg/kg IN
May repeat 0.5mg/kg after 20 minutes X 1
MAX total dose 100 mg/dose IV Systolic BP 70 + 2xAge
See Clinical Considerations for administration guidance</center>

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Ketamine can be administered undiluted over 60 seconds, but may be diluted to 2mg/mL in 0.9% NaCl before administration Ketamine Adverse Reactions: Emergence reactions, hallucinations especially with older children, Hypersalivation, tachycardia, and hypertension, laryngospasm in infants Consider multi-modal approach to analgesia where appropriate. For example, using Acetaminophen + NSAID promotes better pain relief and may reduce opioid requirements
• Use Oral route to administer medications whenever possible
• IM administration is reserved for patients in severe pain without appropriate IV access or suitable routes of admin; use the least invasive route whenever possible
• FLACC pain scoring / assessment must be completed at the start of normal patient care at a frequency that aligns with the patient’s clinical state
• Pain assessment should be completed every 30 minutes as well as with significant changes in patient condition and also before and after interventions
• Match analgesic to the severity of pain

documents.title: Analgosedation: Intubated Patients
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Agitation and lability requiring intubation and ventilation
• Any patient receiving muscle relaxation
• Any patient undergoing invasive procedures
• Any patient who demonstrates positive indications of pain, tachycardia, hypertension or grimacing
• The patient must have a baseline and continuous assessment of response to the drug with heart rate, respiratory rate and blood pressure documented.
• CCPs may administer sedation and analgesia without patching, within the dosage and MAP parameters outlined below. Caution must be taken to avoid sedation/analgesia related hypotension by titrating dosage slowly and to effect utilizing the sedation/analgesia scales below. ALL intubated patients receiving sedation/analgesia should have a sedation and analgesia score calculated, monitored and documented throughout transport.</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Systolic BP below 70 + (2 x age in years)</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Monitor patient for hemodynamic instability with analgosedation infusions
• Systolic BP below 70 + (2 x age in years)
• Some clinical conditions such as suspected ICP (TBI, ICH) or spinal cord injury require higher blood pressure parameters to maintain perfusion</tab1>

drug_cards.title: FentaNYL (Sublimaze)
dose_route:
<center>1-2 microgram/kg/dose slow IV/IO push
q 15 minutes PRN
MAX dose of 4 microgram/kg/hr including infusion</center>

drug_cards.title: Morphine (MSO4)
dose_route:
<center>0.1 mg/kg/dose IV/IO (MAX 4 mg/dose)
0.2 Q 20 minutes PRN</center>

drug_cards.title: Ketamine
dose_route:
<center>1-2 mg/kg slow IV/IO push
Q 10 minutes PRN
Not to exceed 2 mg/kg/hr</center>

drug_cards.title: Ketamine
dose_route:
<center>1-2 mg/kg slow IV/IO push
Q 10 minutes PRN
Not to exceed 2 mg/kg/hr</center>

drug_cards.title: Propofol (Diprivan)
dose_route:
<center>Additional boluses of 0.5 mg/kg/dose
q 5 minutes PRN provided BP is normal for age</center>

<center>0-12 mg/kg/hr titrated
by increments of 0.3 mg/kg/hr
Q 5 minutes PRN</center>

drug_cards.title: DexMEDEtomidine
dose_route:
<center>0.5 – 1.6 mcg/kg/hour IV infusion
Titration by 0.1 mcg/kg/hour q 30 minutes until desired sedation goal or clinical effect
Max dose 2.5 mcg/kg/hour IV if authorized by TMP</center>

documents.title: FLACC (Paediatric) Behavioural Pain Assessment Scale
content: Occasional grimace or frown, withdrawn, disinterested
Frequent to constant frown, clenched jaw, quivering chin
Lying quietly, normal position, moves easily
Squirming, shifting back and forth, tense
Moans or whimpers, occasional complaint, tense
Crying steadily, screams or sobs; frequent complaints
Reassured by occasional touching, hugging, or being talked to; distractible
Severe discomfort or pain or both

documents.title: Sedation Scale For Paediatrics
content:
Spontaneously pays attention to care provider
Unsafe (biting endotracheal tube, pulling at catheters, cannot be left alone)
Unable to console
Increased movement (restless, squirming, or thrashing side-to-side, kicking legs)
May have difficulty breathing with ventilator

Coughing spontaneously
No external stimulus required to elicit response

Responds to voice/no external stimulus is required to elicit response
Drifts off/spontaneously pays attention to care provider
Intermittently unsafe
Does not consistently calm, despite 5-min attempt/unable to console
Increased movement (restless, squirming)
Spontaneous effective breathing/having difficulty breathing with ventilator

Responds to voice/no external stimulus is required to elicit response
Spontaneously pays attention to care provider
Distresses with procedures
Able to calm with comforting touch or voice when stimulus removed
Occasional movement of limbs or shifting of position/increased movement (restless, squirming)
Response to gentle touch or voice

Responds to touch/voice
Able to pay attention but drifts off after stimulation
Distresses with procedures
Able to calm with comforting touch or voice when stimulus removed
Occasional movement of limbs or shifting of position; Follows commands

Responds to noxious stimuli
Unable to pay attention to care provider
Will distress with a noxious procedure
Does not move/occasional movement of limbs or shifting of position

No response to noxious stimuli
Unable to pay attention to care provider
Does not distress with any procedure (including noxious)
Does not move
No cough or coughs only with suctioning

documents.title: Paediatric - Post Intubation Paralysis
documents.indications: • Patients with known difficult airway • To facilitate and optimize mechanical ventilation and oxygenation • Persistent hypoxia/hypoxemia despite adequate sedation • To minimize risk of accidental extubation in transport • In labile patients requiring 100% oxygen
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Inadequate sedation/analgesia</tab1>
documents.clinical: • Sedation/analgesia must be administered in conjunction with muscle relaxation • In patients with known difficult airway, muscle relaxation is strongly recommended post intubation to ensure minimal risk for loss of ETT in transport • Complete history and physical examination (including baseline neurologic assessment) must be completed prior to medication administration • ETT tube confirmed to be in good position on, CXR (if available), auscultation and by EtCO2 tracing confirms ETT placement in the trachea, but does not confirm optimal positioning • Resuscitation equipment should be readily available • All patients must be on a cardiac, SpO2 and EtCO2 monitor, with frequent blood pressure monitoring (typically every 5-10 minutes unless otherwise indicated) • The patient may require increased ventilatory support once muscle related • Baseline assessment of patient’s response (heart rate, blood pressure) to paralytic must be obtained and re-evaluated to determine need for further sedation and ongoing muscle relaxation • Muscle relaxants will hide the motor component of seizures. In cases of status epilepticus or risk of seizures, paralysis should be administered as a last resort and in conjunction with anticonvulsant/sedative infusions. Monitor closely for autonomic manifestations of seizures

documents.title: Paediatric - Non-Traumatic Cardiac Arrest: PCP
documents.indications: <tab1>• Vital signs absent (VSA) due to non-traumatic cause</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Vital signs present</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• PCP may apply the Medical Directives for the management of cardiac arrest with semi-automated defibrillation
• The above chart shows all possible Joule settings based on the two types of monitors currently used by Ornge in both manual and SAED settings
• Joule settings in the algorithms above are based on the Zoll X MD Manual settings as this is the most prevalent monitor in our system
• TMP patch prior to initiating transport of patient in cardiac arrest for consideration of TOR</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Non-Traumatic Cardiac Arrest: ACP(f)
documents.indications: <tab1>• Vital signs absent (VSA) due to non–traumatic cause</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Vital signs present
• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine
dose_route:
0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000 concentration)
Repeat q 3-5 min

drug_cards.title: AmioDARONE
dose_route:
5 mg/kg (MAX 300 mg/dose) rapid bolus during cardiac arrest
May repeat up to 2 times to a MAX total dose of 15 mg/kg for refractory VF/pulseless VT

drug_cards.title: Lidocaine
dose_route:
Initial 1 mg/kg loading dose
Maintenance infusion 20-50 microgram/kg/min
(repeat bolus dose if infusion initiated > 15 min after initial bolus therapy)

documents.clinical: <tab1>• Lidocaine continuous IV infusion: Do not exceed 20 microgram/kg/min in patients with shock, hepatic disease, cardiac arrest or CHF</tab1>

documents.title: Neonatal Resuscitation (NRP)
documents.indications: • Neonatal vital signs absent
documents.contraindications: • Allergy or sensitivity to the medication

dose_route: Normal Saline and/or Blood as indicated
drug_cards.notes:
*IV or UVC route is preferred
<tab1>IV or IO Epinephrine dose range is 0.01‐0.03 mg/kg
ETT Epinephrine dose range is 0.05‐0.1 mg/kg</tab1>

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Epinephrine should be administered rapidly
• Flush with 3ml nomal saline
• Repeat every 3-5 minutes if heart rate remains <60
• ETT Epinephrine: Administer ETT breaths to distribute into lungs. No flush
• Administration of Narcan is not recommended in the initial steps of resuscitation
• *UVC/IV/IO route preferred. May consider giving one dose of EPINEPHrine via the tracheal tube (ET) while obtaining vascular access. If EPINEPHrine given by ET route and no response, as soon as UVC or IO access obtained administer IV Epinephrine dose immediately. Do not wait 3-5 minutes after initial ET dose
• Preparation for Transport:
</tab1><tab2>o Anticipate need for thermoregulation during initial steps of resuscitation, especially in premature infants < 32 weeks GA; all neonates require continuous temperature monitoring during initial resuscitation, stabilization and transport. Target normal temperatures 36.5 to 37.5 ̊C
o Following initial steps of resuscitation, target preductal oxygen saturations 90% to 95%; In neonates with suspected congenital heart disease requiring Alprostadil infusion, review preductal oxygen saturation target with TMP
o In neonates with suspected persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn, target preductal oxygen saturations 92% to 95%</tab2>
<tab1>• Administration of a volume expander is indicated if the baby is not responding to resuscitation and there are signs of shock or a history of acute blood loss
• Infants in hypovolemic shock may appear pale with delayed capillary refill and /or weak pulses
• Packed red blood cells should be considered for volume replacement when severe fetal anemia is suspected</tab1>

documents.title: Post - Cardiac Arrest Care Check List
content: Provide continuous SpO2 monitoring and target normoxemia 94% to 99% (or child’s normal/appropriate oxygen saturation)
Provide continuous EtCO2 monitoring and target PaCO2, appropriate to child’s underlying condition and limit exposure to severe hypercapnia and hypercapnia
Set specific hemodynamic goals during post –cardiac arrest care; Review BP target with TMP
Monitor arterial blood pressure if available
Monitor serum lactate and urine output
Use parental fluid bolus with or without inotropes or vasopressors to maintain a systolic blood pressure greater the 5th percentile for age
Prevent and treat fever immediately after arrest
Monitor closely for and treat seizures immediately
Monitor blood glucose and avoid hypoglycemia
Maintain electrolytes within normal ranges to avoid life-threatening arrhythmias

documents.title: Paediatric - Bradycardia
documents.indications: Bradycardia
documents.contraindications: Allergy or sensitivity to the medication

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine
dose_route:
0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000 concentration) IV
Repeat q 3-5 min

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine
dose_route:
0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000 concentration) IV
Repeat q 3-5 min
OR
0.1 microgram/kg/min IV infusion

drug_cards.title: Atropine
dose_route:
0.02 mg/kg IV/IO
MAX single dose: Child 0.5 mg; Adolescent 1 mg
May repeat dose once

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Atropine Dose ETT if no IV/IO access: 0.04- 0.06 mg/kg/dose for symptomatic bradycardia
• Atropine for Toxins/overdose (i.e. organophosphate, carbamate)</tab1><tab2>
o < 12 years: 0.02- 0.05 mg/kg IV/IO initially; repeat q 20-30 minutes until symptoms are reversed
o > 12 years: 2 mg IV/IO initially; then 1-2 mg IV/IO q 20-30 minutes until symptoms are reversed</tab2>

documents.title: Paediatric - Tachycardia
documents.indications: <tab1>• Tachycardia</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

dose_route:
Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg rapid IV/IO bolus (MAX 6 mg)
followed by rapid Normal Saline flush 5-10 ml
Repeat Adenosine at 0.2 mg/kg q 2 min if no change

drug_cards.title: Procedural Sedation
dose_route: Ketamine 0.5 mg/kg OR Midazolam 0.05 mg/kg and/or FentaNYL 1 microgram/kg

documents.clinical: <tab1>• Adenosine should be administered in peripheral IV site close to patient's heat. Two syringes (one with Adenosine dose and one with NS flush) connected to a T-connector or stopcock is recommended for rapid administration of both medication and flush</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Intravenous Line Initiation and Maintenance
documents.indications: <tab1>• Actual or potential need for intravenous drug or fluid therapy</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Suspected fracture proximal to the IV site</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Monitor
dose_route: Infants and children with an IV in place infusing at a rate of 5-15 mL/hr TKVO

Calculate IV rate of 80 mL/kg/day
Preferred solution D10W
Neonate (> 24 hours old) (< 28 days or 44 weeks corrected gestational age)

Calculate IV rate at 100 mL/kg/day
Preferred solution D10W & 0.2% Saline
(D5W & 0.9% NaCL) may be indicated in some circumstances

4 mL/hr x (0-10 kg)
+ 2 mL/hr x (10.1 kg-20 kg)
+ 1 mL/hr x (20.1 kg and greater)
D5W & 0.9% NaCL IV
0.9% normal saline may be indicated for maintenance when blood glucose levels are high

documents.clinical: <tab1>• If administering KCL in maintenance infusion, ensure K is < 5 and patient passing urine</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Intraosseous Initiation and Maintenance
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Inadequate intravenous access for resuscitation
• Unable to obtain intravenous access after two (2) attempts or 90 seconds</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Known or suspected fracture of affected limb
• Known or suspected injury, deformity, or infection overlying the proposed insertion site
• Absence of adequate anatomic landmarks
• Inability to identify anatomical landmarks</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate intervention based upon the presenting condition

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• In neonatal patients an IO can be placed in the proximal tibia
• For neonates < 10 days of age and less than 3 kg, consider UVC Insertion
• Paediatric IOs can be placed in the proximal and distal tibia, distal femur and the humerus</tab1><tab2>
o Choosing the site is based on ability to identify anatomical landmark
</tab2><tab1>• Clinical judgement should be used to determine the appropriate needle set selection based on patient anatomy, insertion site, weight and tissue depth
• If the EZ-IO is secured especially in infant due to softer, thinner boned in this population
• A general flush volume of 2-5 ml is recommended for infants and small children
• Confirm IO placement by: stability of catheter, ability to aspsirate blood or marrow (inability to aspirate/withdraw blood from the catheter does not mean the insertion was unsuccessful), adequate flow rate</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Intraosseous Vascular Access Analgesia
documents.indications: <tab1>• Patient requiring intraosseous (IO) needle access and responsive to pain</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Sino-atrial disorders
• All grades of AV block, Stokes-Adams syndrome, Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
• Acute porphyria
• Hypersensitivity to another local anesthetic of the amide type</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Lidocaine 2% without epinephrine
drug_cards.notes: *Administer first dose over 2 minutes then allow lidocaine to dwell for 1 minute in IO space and flush with 5-10 ml 0.9% saline Followed by second dose of lidocaine over 1 minute

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• After the second lidocaine dose is given, medication or fluids may be administered under pressure as required
• Can consider administering again in 45 minutes later at the lower of the two previous doses given if discomfort re-occurs
• If extravasation occurs insert a new IO needle
• Cimetidine or beta-blockers (e.g. propranol) may interact and cause lidocaine toxicity</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Umbilical Vein Catheterization
documents.indications:
<tab1>• No parenteral access is available in a newborn that requires IV therapy emergently (i.e. during neonatal resuscitation)
• When IV access cannot be obtained
• To treat hypoglycemia when IV dextrose concentration is greater than D12.5W</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

dose_route:
Recommended sizes for procedure are:
# 3.5 Fr for infants < 26+6 weeks gestation
# 5 Fr for infants > 27 weeks gestational age

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Initiate the appropriate intervention based upon the presenting condition
• The umbilical vein is usually the most accessible vein in a newborn
• UVCs inserted with the catheter tip below the liver, and are considered ‘low lines’
• Do not substitute feeding tubes for Umbilical Venous Catheters</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Venous/Capillary Blood Sampling and Lab Value Interpretation
documents.indications:
<tab1>• To establish baseline respiratory, cardiovascular, hematological status prior to or during transport
• To monitor changes and/or deterioration in clinical status</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

dose_route: Perform venipuncture, venous/capillary blood sampling and utilize iSTAT if available

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Should be reviewed with Paediatric TMP on patch
• Management based on these results will be via patch with the Paediatric TMP
• Mechanically ventilated patients should have point of care samples obtained for gas interpretation and ventilation titration, if recent samples are not readily available from the sending facilitiy. Typically, samples should be taken enroute, to avoid unnecessary delays in initiating transport
• In severe DKA patients as per algorithm to monitor gases, electrolytes and glucose</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Central Venous and Arterial Line Monitoring
documents.indications: <tab1>• Established arterial and venous line</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• PCPs may not access, maintain or monitor a central venous access device (CVAD)</tab1>

dose_route: Monitor an established central venous line using the following heparin concentrations: 2 units/mL added to Normal Saline for all infants and children 1 unit/mL added to Normal Saline for all neonates (under 28 days)

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• All paediatric central lines require heparinized fluids to maintain patency
• All paediatric arterial lines require heparinized fluids to maintain patency
• This directive does not permit access to venous devices that are located subcutaneously, such as a PortaCath or similar
• Arterial lines are calibrated (zeroed) with any changes in level of bed &/or position of head of bed to transducer, if waveform changes and with IV tubing changes
• Ensure all connections are tight , line is secured (i.e. arm board) and limb properly restrained as required
• Blood backing up the transducer tubing from the patient may indicate a leak, crack or loose connections</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Seizures
documents.indications: • Active seizure
documents.contraindications:
• If blood glucose < 3 mmol/L, proceed with “Hypoglycemic Emergencies”. Concurrently, medicate with a benzodiazepine (as stated below) for treatment of seizure
• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication

drug_cards.title: Midazolam (Versed)
dose_route:
<center>0.1 mg/kg IV/IO (MAX 4 mg)
OR
0.2 mg/kg IN/IM (MAX 5 mg)*</center>
drug_cards.notes: * Dose limit for intranasal (IN) is 2.5 mg/2.5 ml per nostril

drug_cards.title: Midazolam (Versed)
dose_route:
Midazolam infusion: initiate at 50 microgram/kg/hour q 5 min to a MAX of 1400 microgram/kg/hour
Bolus with 0.15 mg/kg/dose to MAX of 4 mg/dose IV/IO prior to each titration

dose_route:
<center>60 mg/kg/dose IV/IO MAX 3000 mg/dose
Infuse over 5 minutes</center>

drug_cards.title: LORazepam (Ativan)

0.1 mg/kg IV/IO
To a MAX of 4 mg
May repeat q 5 minutes
To a MAX of 8 mg

dose_route:
20 mg PE*/kg IV/IM Infuse over 5 to 10 mins
MAX dose 3 mL/site IM
If > 30 kg, requires multiple sites
drug_cards.notes: *PE (phenyTOIN equivalents)

drug_cards.title: phenyTOIN (Dilantin)
dose_route: 20 mg mg/kg IV/IM Infuse over 20 mins Note: USE NORMAL SALINE ONLY as phenyTOIN will precipitate in dextrose solutions

documents.clinical: • If the seizure is not terminated within five 5 minutes of administration of Midazolam, AND the ACP(f), CCP is unable to establish contact with the TMP, a repeat dose of Midazolam (0.1 mg/kg IV) may be administered • Seizures lasting longer than 5 minutes are unlikely to stop spontaneously. The longer seizures continue the more difficult they are to abort with medications • Fosphenytoin is the preferred medication over PhenyTOIN due to its enhanced safety profile and should be given in preference if available • 0.2 micron filter must be used when administering phenyTOIN • No micron filter is required to administer Fosphenytoin • Fosphenytoin/ phenyTOIN should not be used with a diagnosis of toxic ingestion or in the setting of a cardiac conduction system disturbance • Consider reducing the rate of phenyTOIN administration to 25 mg/min in children with cardiac conditions • If the patient is hemodynamically unstable and there is no IV access, consider placing an IO • Administration: Do not give undiluted. Compatible when mixed with 0.9% NaCl, D5W, & Ringer's Lactate. • In infants & older children: o For doses < 200 mg dilute to 20mg/ml; Infuse over 15 minutes o For doses > 200 mg dilute to 40 mg/ml; Infuse over 15 minutes

documents.indications: <tab1>• Cardiac arrest due to trauma</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Vital signs present</tab1>

dose_route:
20 mL/kg IV bolus
MAX 1 L
Target SBP 70 + (2x age)
Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• PCP may apply the Medical Directives for the management of cardiac arrest with semi-automated defibrillation
• TMP patch prior to initiating transport of patient in cardiac arrest for consideration of TOR</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Severe Traumatic Brain Injury (GCS < 8, Abnormal CT)

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the flowchart

documents.title: Paediatric - Hemorrhagic Shock
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Acute paediatric hypovolemia
• Children exhibiting manifestations of cardiovascular compromise: delayed capillary refill time (> 3 seconds), poor peripheral pulses, pale and/or mottling, cool extremities, tachycardia
• Hypotensive children
• Children in cardiopulmonary arrest</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Known hypersensitivity, adverse side effects or newly presenting side effects
• Parents refuse treatment/blood product-consult with TMP
• Blood products when parents are known Jehovah Witness-consult with TMP</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• *In hypotensive DKA patients fluid boluses should be more conservative (Normal Saline 10 mL/kg IV over 1 hr)

• Reassess patient response to fluid bolus (i.e. Assess for decrease in heart rate, improved capillary refill time, improved pulses and urine output)
• Severe hypovolemia from blood loss should prompt consideration for the early use of blood products. In cases requiring massive transfusion include both packed red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma</tab1>

documents.title: Paediatric - Massive Hemorrhage Protocol
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Obvious critical bleeding
• Acute paediatric hemorrhagic shock
• Poor BP response to fluids administration</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Patient has not been transfused with up to 20ml/kg of RBC. Re-evaluate need for MHP after 20ml/kg.
• Known hypersensitivity, adverse side effects or newly presenting side effects
• Parents refuse treatment/blood product-consult with TMP
• Blood products when parents are known Jehovah’s Witness-consult with TMP</tab1>
documents.treatment:
<tab1>• Rapidly control hemorrhage (direct pressure, tourniquet, etc.).
• Obtain IV/IO access
• Tranexamic acid (TXA) administration
• Infuse all “pack 1” RBC’s (20 ml/kg/dose) BEFORE “Pack 2” products, UNLESS lab results direct otherwise
• Limit use of crystalloids (max 20ml/kg > then RBC)
• Administer Calcium according to dosing regimen noted below
• Keep patient core temperatures above 36°C
• Collect MHP/trauma labs including iSTAT
• Reverse anticoagulation if applicable
• Initiate transport for definitive bleeding control</tab1>

<tab1>• Patient must be on a cardio-respiratory monitor, with frequent blood pressure monitoring

documents.title: Paediatric - Push Dose Epinephrine – 10 mcg/ml (1:100 000)
documents.indications: <tab1>• Restoration of circulation temporarily, during paediatric PERI-ARREST and shock states presenting with severe hypotension and/or bradycardia for ages</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Patients receiving chest compressions
• Patients in cardiac arrest</tab1>
documents.clinical: • During CARDIAC ARREST only a dose 10 mcg/kg of Epinephrine 1: 10 000 (100 mcg/ml) Pre-loaded syringe (1 mg/10 ml) should be used • Types of critically ill patients in whom Epinephrine 1: 100 000 may be considered include: o Acute Hypotension in severe shock states o Heart Disease (e.g. unstable coronary perfusion, cardiomyopathy, heart failure, myocarditis) Prior to intubation in patients with shock o Patients on Epinephrine infusions >0.5 mcg/kg/min • Epinephrine 1: 100 000 allows for restoration of circulation temporarily and avoids tachycardia and vasoconstriction that can occur with CARDIAC ARREST doses (10 mcg/kg) • Epinephrine 1: 100 000 may provide temporary stabilization while other therapies are added or adjusted/titrated • Delivered as a concentration of Epinephrine 1: 100 000 ( 10 micrograms/ml) which is equal to a dose volume of 0.1 ml/kg/dose Preparation of Epinephrine 1: 100 000 1. Using a 10 ml syringe, draw 100 microgram 1mg/ml (i.e. 1 ml of 1: 10 000/100mg/ml) EPINEPHrine and dilute in 9 ml of Normal Saline.

documents.title: Paediatric - Septic Shock
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Cardiovascular dysfunction (hypotension [SBP < 70 + (2x age)], prolonged capillary refill, oliguria, metabolic acidosis, elevated arterial lactate)
• Hemodynamic abnormalities persist despite > 40 mL/kg of fluid in one hour
• GCS < 11</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.clinical: • Recognition of Severe Sepsis: • Fever (> 38.0 C) or hypothermia (<36.0 C) • Signs of infection (cough/chest pain/respiratory distress; abdominal pain/distention/vomiting/diarrhea, skin/joint pain/swelling/rash, decreased feeding, decreased urine output • Tachycardia, capillary refill >2 seconds, cold extremities, decreased urine output, SpO2 < 94%, mottled skin • Mental status changes (confusion, lethargy, inconsolability) • Initial management should include: • IV access X2; IO access if 2 failed IV attempts • May use IO to obtain blood samples • Administer fluid boluses Normal Saline 20 ml/kg IV over 5-10 minutes (reassess HR, RR, BP, perfusion, SpO2 (Palpate for hepatomegaly, auscultate for crackles) • Consider cardiogenic shock if deterioration after fluid boluses • Paediatrics are seldom in a pure warm shock state; Norepinephrine is rarely used as first line agent • Norepinephrine is for patients who are CLEARLY in warm shock state (wide pulse pressure, warm extremities, bounding pulses, brisk CRT) • Children are often significantly hypovolemic (from not keeping up with insensibles & 3rd spacing; especially infants who don't control their intake), therefore have a component of cold (vasoconstricted shock), myocardial dysfunction (occurs earlier in sepsis in paediatrics) and therefore an element of cardiogenic shock (cold shock) • Prepare 2nd line inotropes early • Monitor peripheral infusions of Epinephrine & Norepinephrine > 0.05 mcg/kg/min closely for signs of extravasation. In profound hypotension, infusions may be titrated > 0.1 mcg/kg/min, but this is not optimal in peripheral IV sites and should be discussed with Paediatric TMP • Physiologic indicators and target goals: strong distal pulses equal to central pulses, warm peripheries with CRT < 2 seconds, improved GCS (normal mental status), urine output > 1 ml/kg/hr, BP although not in itself a reliable endpoint for resuscitation, systolic BP 60 mmHg in infants , 1 month old; 70 mmHg + (2 x age in years) in children 1 month to 10 years of age; 90mm Hg in children 10 years of age or older • Vancomycin can be added by TMP based on severity of infection and risk factors in catchment area. Vancomycin should not be given without a patch

documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Esophageal strictures

• Patients receiving Anticoagulants. Anticoagulants include but are not limited to: unfractionated heparin IV bolus or infusion, Warfarin (Coumadin), Enoxaparin (Lovenox), or NOACs/DOACs</tab1>

Patch for further management • Patient may require EPINEPHrine infusion in severe exacerbations if no improvement >3 doses of IM epinephrine • If persistent hypotension or decrease LOC start Epinephrine infusion at 0.05 mcg/kg/min IV and titrate up by 0.05 mcg/kg/min increments to effect • Be prepared for potentially difficult airway

documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Risk Factors for Hypoglycemia:</tab1><tab2>
o Prematurity (< 37 wks GA), SGA, IUGR, LGA, IDM</tab2>
<tab1>• Inborn errors of metabolism, endocrine disorders (related to glucose homeostasis)
• maternal treatment with beta-sympathomimetic agents (beta blockers)
• severe hepatic dysfunction
• Asphyxia, stress
• Establish or increase IV infusion and calculate Glucose infusion rate (GIR)
• Initial GIR should be 4-6 mg/kg/min
• Glucose infusion rate: mg/kg/minute = IV rate (ml/hr) X glucose concentration mg/ml)/ weight (kg)/60 min
• Glucose in IV fluids:</tab1>n/<tab2>D5W: 50 mg/ml
D10W: 100 mg/ml
D12.5W: 125 mg/ml</tab2>
<tab1>• Can increase GIR by increasing TFI (hrly IV rate) and/or increasing Dextrose concentration in IVF</tab1>
At-risk infants for hypoglycemia: SGA, IUGR, LGA, IDM, GA < 37 weeks, asphyxia, maternal exposure to labetalol, late preterm antenatal steroids. Give 40% dextrose gel 0.5 mL/kg AND feed 5 mL/kg and breastfeed. Check glucose 30 min post-feed 4 OR feed 8 m. documents.title: Paediatric - Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Hyperglycemia (blood glucose > 11 mmol/L) in a new or known diabetic
AND
• pH <7.30 and serum bicarbonate <15 mmol/L
AND (if available)
• Confirmed ketosis (positive ketones in blood or urine)</tab1>
<title>Monitoring</title>
<tab1>• Cardiorespiratory monitor and O2 saturation monitor
• Monitoring of vital signs (HR, RR, BP) and neurovitals, q 10-15 minutes
• Accurate intake and output q 1 hour
• Bedside glucose q 1 hour</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• All Paediatric patients < 18 years of age should be managed using the paediatric DKA algorithm
• History/Handover</tab1>
<tab2>• Clarify history of oral intake, urine output, weight loss, complaints of headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, generalized weakness and other medical conditions and current medications
• Ask family or sending healthcare providers about any precipitating factors such as concurrent illness;
• in patients with known diabetes, review Insulin dosages and adherence to care plan, any new medications or the possibility of pregnancy</tab2>
<tab1>• NEVER start insulin infusion before 1st hour of IV fluids has been started
• NEVER bolus IV insulin
• Add 5% dextrose (D5W & 0.9% NaCl) to IV fluid once blood glucose is less than 17 mmol/L or if blood glucose is decreasing by more than 5 mmol/L/hr after Insulin infusion has started
• Increase IV fluids to 10% dextrose (D10W & 0.9% NaCl) as required in discussion with TMP to keep blood glucose >10 mmol/L</tab1>
Patients at RISK for Cerebral Injury include:<tab2>
• Cerebral Injury may complicate any episode of paediatric DKA
• Children who present with a longer duration of symptoms; patient appears unwell
• Greater acidosis at time of presentation & hypocapnia
• Evidence of more severe dehydration (Increased HCT, Urea)
• Presentation in younger children (< 5 yrs old)
• New onset diabetes</tab2>
