drug_cards.title: Calcium Gluconate 2 % (20mg/mL)
dose_route:
<center>50-200 mg/kg/dose IV/IO
Infuse over 30-60 minutes
Infuse at a rate not to exceed 4 mg Calcium Gluconate/kg/min to a maximum of 150 mg of Calcium Gluconate/minute
See Reconstitution Instructions</center>

documents.title: Paediatric - Hyperkalemia
documents.indications:
<tab1>• Abnormal ECG
• Muscular weakness or paralysis
• Serum or plasma K+ >6 mmol/l
• Serum or plasma K+ between 6 and 7 mmol/L with ongoing risk of continued rise off K+ due to tumor lysis or major crush injury</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Spurious sample (blood specimen is hemolyzed)</tab1>
documents.clinical:
<tab1>• Assess CABs and LOC
• Stop K+ infusions
• Specimen hemolyzed? Consider repeat K+
• For infants < 6 months of age, consider using 2 mL/kg/dose Sodium Bicarbonate 4.2 % 0.5 mmol/L<tab1>

drug_cards.title: Calcium Gluconate 10% (100 mg/ml)
dose_route:
<center>60 mg/kg IV/IO over 5 minutes
0.6 mL/kg diluted in equal volume of NS or D5W maximum dose 2 grams
Repeat q 10-20 minutes for persistent ECG changes or arrhythmias</center>

drug_cards.title: Calcium Chloride 10% (100 mg/mL)
dose_route:
<center> 20mg/kg IV/IO slow push (over 10-20 seconds)
(0.2 mL/kg) Maximum dose 2 grams
May Repeat in 10 minutes</center>

drug_cards.title: Regular Human Insulin (10 units/mL)
dose_route:
<center>0.1 units/kg in 5 mL/kg D10W IV/IO
Over 30 min</center>

drug_cards.title: Salbutamol
dose_route:
<center>100mcg/puff
< 20 kg 5 puffs q 15 min x 3
>20 kg 10 puffs q 15 min x 3</center>

documents.title: Paediatric - Suspected Opioid Overdose
documents.indications:
<tab1>• GCS of < 12 or altered level of consciousness
AND
• Respiratory rate < 10
AND
• Suspected acute opioid overdose</tab1>
documents.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• If Blood glucose < 3 mmol/L, proceed with “Hypoglycemic Emergencies”</tab1>
documents.clinical: <tab1>• Management of airway, breathing and circulation remain the first priority: adequate oxygenation and ventilation must be ensured</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Naloxone (Narcan)
dose_route:
0.1 mg/kg IM every 2 minutes prn
(up to a MAX total of 0.1 mg/kg or 2 mg)

drug_cards.title: Naloxone (Narcan)
dose_route:
0.1 mg/kg
IV, IM, IO or ETT every 2 minutes prn
(up to a MAX total of 0.1 mg/kg or 2 mg) (IV/IO route, followed by IM route are preferred)

documents.title: Paediatric - Suspected Acetaminophen Toxicity
documents.indications: <tab1>• Suspected acetaminophen toxicity</tab1>
documents.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
documents.clinical: • Mandatory Patch required to initiate an acetylcysteine infusion • The ACP(f), CCP and PCCP/PCCN may maintain the administration of a MucomystTM (acetylcysteine) infusion for an acetaminophen overdose in the following circumstances: o The infusion was initiated by the sending facility o Ingested or suspected ingestion of acetaminophen dose is greater or equal to: • 7.5 gm OR • 150 mg/kg o The rate of infusion is in accordance with the accompanying dosage table and preparation guide o The rate of infusion cannot be altered by the Paramedic unless ordered by the Transport Medicine Physician o High Risk dosing based on acetaminophen levels, liver enzymes, need for dialysis, altered mental status, lactic acidosis o IV infusion for at least 8 hours until advised to stop by Poison Centre Guidelines to Prepare a 3% Intravenous N-Acetylcysteine Bag As part of the Poison Centre’s treatment recommendations for the acetaminophen-poisoned patient, a 3 % n-acetylcysteine solution will need to be prepared. The following are instructions on how to prepare this solution in D5W. Patient is <20 kg: • Remove 37.5 ml from a 250 ml bag of D5W • Add 37.5 ml of 20% IV N-Acetylcysteine to the remaining 212.5 ml in the D5W bag o 37.5 ml X 200mg/ml = 7 500 mg of N-Acetylcysteine o 7500 mg in 250 ml yields a final solution with 30 mg/ml or 3% Patient is 21-40 kg: • Remove 75 ml from a 500 ml bag of D5W • Add 75 ml of 20% IV N-Acetylcysteine to the remaining 425 ml in the D5W bag o 75 ml X 200mg/ml = 15 000 mg of N-Acetylcysteine o 15 000 mg in 500 ml yields a final solution with 30 mg/ml or 3% If patient is >40 kg, refer to the adult directives for preparation instructions. Notes: 1. 20% IV N-Acetylcysteine is equivalent to 200 mg/mL 2. The 3% solution is slightly hyperosmolar but still within the safety margin for administration via a peripheral vein 3. It is recognized that any particular bag of IV fluid could have excessive fluid more than advertised. It is of little consequence when making this 3% solution. Assume a finished volume as advertised on the bag Mixing is important to ensure uniform distribution of N-Acetylcysteine in infusion solution.

drug_cards.title: Maintenance Infusion: 3% Mucomyst (Acetylcysteine) Dosage Guide and Preparation for IV Administration (reference CPS)
dose_route: Initial Infusion 60 mg/kg/hr x 4 hrs Dose limit: 6000 mg/hr
*High Risk* Maintenance Infusion 12 mg/kg/hr Used only in consultation with Poison Centre Dose limit: 1200 mg/hr

documents.title: Guideline for Paediatric Vital Signs/Tube Sizes
content: Initial endotracheal tube insertion depth ('tip to lip') for orotracheal intubation
Adapted from Kempley ST, Moreira JW, Petrone FL. Endotracheal tube length for neonatal intubation. Resuscitation. 2008;77(3):369-373

<tab1>• Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) is variable based on patient age and cuff size, systolic blood pressure is less impacted by this, therefore thresholds for blood pressure interventions or precautions are based on systolic pressure in the < 12 years or < 40 kg paediatric population
• Blood pressures listed in the table above are within the 50 percentile for age/weight
• BroselowTM/paediatric tape version acceptable
• ETT size formula: one year of age or more:</tab1><tab2>
o Uncuffed = (Age in years)/4) + 4 = tube size in mm
o Cuffed=(Age in years)/4) + 3.5 = tube size in mm
o Cuffed ETT’s should be used in all paediatric patients except newborns</tab2>

documents.title: Paediatric Medication Matrix
content: ■ Indicates included in F-RN scope only when paired with a CCP
The CCP may administer any medication under the direction of the TMP provided that they are familiar with the drug and comfortable with managing its administration and potential side effects.

documents.title: Critical Care Resident Meds & Procedures Matrix
content: Critical Care Residents can perform to the scope of practice noted in this document while supervised by a qualified preceptor.
EPINEPHrine (IV Push ONLY for ACLS/ NRP)

Legend:
I=Initiate
M=Monitoring Only
T=Troubleshoot and Adjust
Advanced Airway Management: Bougie, Direct or Video Laryngoscopy (VL)
Balloon tamponade of gastroesophageal varices monitoring (Blakemore tubes)
Cardiac ECG monitoring and interpretation - Lead II, 12-lead, 15-lead STEMI recognition
Intravenous initiation (peripheral, external jugular & infantscalp vein)
Mechanical ventilation - patients < 28 days of age
Mechanical ventilation - patients > 28 days of age
Pulmonary artery catheter monitoring and/ or removal
Transport Isolette - Care of a neonate
Vascular access- Peripheral venous and Capillary

documents.title: Paediatric Procedure List
content: Legend: M - Monitoring I - Initiation (includes troubleshooting) T - Troubleshooting (includes monitoring) ** indicates included in F-RN scope when paired with an ACP(f) or CCP
Advanced Airway Management: Bougie, Direct or Video Laryngoscopy (VL)
Blood analysis (Point of Care – iSTAT etc.)
Blood sampling – Peripheral venous and capillary
Cardiac ECG monitoring and interpretation - All leads including 12 and 15-lead
Intravenousinitiation (peripheral, external jugular & infant scalp vein)
Mechanical ventilation – patient < 28 days of age
Mechanical ventilation – patient > 28 days of age

Obstetrics: 
External uterine massage, Gaskin maneuvre, H.E.L.P.E.R. maneuvers (shoulder dystocia), Mariceau-Smellie-Veit  maneuvre, McRoberts maneuvre, Umbilical cord management
Transport Isolette - Care of a neonate
Vascular access – Peripheral venous and capillary

documents.title: Privacy Policy
content: Ornge Base Hospital Medical Directive App Effective date: August 26, 2020 The Ornge Base Hospital Medical Directives mobile application (“Medical Directive App”) is operated by Ornge (“us”, “we”, or “our”) for the benefit of Ontario paramedics certified by Ornge’s Base Hospital. At the time of launching this application, when you use or download our Medical Directives App, we do not collect, use, disclose, retain or have access to any of your Personal Information, as that term is defined in the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act (Ontario). If in the future, the Medical Directives App changes such that Ornge collects, uses, discloses, retains or accesses your personal information when using or downloading the App, Ornge will do so in accordance with the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act (Ontario) or other applicable law. Contact Us: Should you have questions about this Privacy Policy, please contact us at privacy@ornge.ca.
